posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Can we talk about it? Played through this over the course of a month, was a lot of fun albeit a little on the easy side. I managed to beat it without using any armor plates whatsoever and the only time I was legitimately getting wrecked were at the atlas tower. I never hear about this game ever, also really bummed that you can't continue after beating it, my hopes were low as it's a 30 year old game but just a static unskippable The End screen was a crushing blow. I loved the characters and the story, do they return at all in later FM games? Genoce and Sakata were the coolest, really wish there was more need to bring support wanzers on missions, you could beat the game by using none ever except Luven to blast the launch tunnel and Sakata to block the laser in that boss fight. Post your thoughts about this game, it's a more fleshed out Metal Warriors, little less style and mech variety, but some good customization great music and fantastic story, I played on an Analogue Pocket.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596585
Not aware of any. And it wouldn't work over a high latency connection without some sort of emulation fuckery to keep things in sync. I've built serial bridges for this and other consoles using various types of connectivity, usb, ethernet, wifi, bt. Games will fail at the speed test or randomly later even on local wifi. Ethernet works, but only locally. As soon as you insert a router it goes to shit. Seems you need very low latency (<1ms) for it to be useable. For games that is. Wifi/BT, etc work fine for most simple sio utils.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596046
I guess I’d say Goldeneye. But an argument could be made for either. I always thought Perfect Dark lost a bit of steam in the last couple of levels, around the time you start shooting skedar instead of people. Goldeneye had more levels and some of them were actually more interesting. PD had longer levels and some cool guns like the x-ray gun. Multiplayer in PD was obviously a step above Goldeneye since it was the same thing but 2 or 3 years later and more refined. I’m sure some people will complain about framerate ir how pc games were better but I’d say these along with Powerslave, Duke, Quake, Doom and Doom 64 are the best console FPS games of their day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
James Pond is one of those European Amiga games that got console releases too.
Whenever people talk about it, it's always the second game Robocod, and I think usually the Genesis / Mega Drive version, and it's been re-released of a shitload of systems in some fashion, even Switch.

Nobody really talks about the original game that was a James Bond MGM parody, or about the third game which is set in outer space. James Pond 3 is pretty solid and gets ledicrously fast, much faster than Sonic does on his home system.
There was also an Olympics spin-off game that's often forgotten.

Also, all the covers for James Pond games always depict him holding a gun, parodying the James Bond movie posters, but I don't think he actually uses one in the games?

Frames of delay, giving the rollback netcode the leeway to work. More frames of delay means higher input lag (ovbiously) but a stabler experience (less teleports)
A combination of brute-forcing+coding magic results in Slippi having 2 less frames of input lag compared to console, so that means that playing with 2f is effectively the same delay as console+CRT (provided you have a good monitor)

>>9591461
I'm a Link main, and while it's true quite a bit of lag was lopped off his movements and some of his attacks in Brawl and afterward, he's still MUCH more fun to play in Melee regardless once you've gained a degree of mastery over his moveset. You can projectile spam to your heart's content, with a great deal of control over his projectiles (his bombs have great interaction potential, as does his boomerang). You can settle for a balance of projectile spam at long range with shffld aerials in the short range. Or you can even surprise your opponents and go on a full retard aggressive shffld aerial offensive with few to no projectiles (this last one is the weakest, but can catch opponents off-guard since not many would play Link this way). His edge and recovery game is also fun thanks to his wall tethers which give him tools to keep the opponent guessing as to your recovery path. Mind you, despite all this he still gets shit on by the top tiers, especially the space animals, but he's not as clunky as people think, and he's horribly simplified in later versions and IMO nowhere near as fun to dick around with.

>>9592695
Link and Y. Link's Hookshot and Samus's Grapple Beam. When used off-stage, unlike in Brawl and beyond, they can hang onto pretty much any wall at any point, and several cool things can be done with them. You can extend them up and down, and can be canceled with a button press at any point from the moment they make contact with the wall to when you're hanging down, at which point your character will quickly "jump" upwards. If you're skilled, this makes their recoveries more dynamic and can keep the opponent guessing as to your recovery path, and IIRC you can even attack out of cancelling. It's really fucking fun, and their removal in favor of a boring auto-snap onto the ledge was a travesty but in keeping with Sakurai's overall drive to casualize the shit out of Smash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592276
>>9592278
You don't need a FX2 chip. All the FX2 did was support larger ROMs than the FX1, the FX1 otherwise performs the same as the FX2. Many people assumed the FX1 runs slower from trying to use Star Fox 1 as the doner cart, but the chip used in Star Fox 1 was slower variant called the Mario Chip. The ROM of Star Fox 2 is small enough to be fully addressable with the FX1. The most likely reason that Star Fox 2 was going to use a FX2 chip is that they were probably not producing the FX1 anymore, not that it needed it. Even if the FX2 cost more to make, having production of both FX1 and FX2 going on at the same time when any FX1 game would run the same on a FX2 would have cost more.

There are far less games that had a FX2 in them, and even less that had battery SRAM. About your only option outside of Tealand is Doom and Yoshi's Island, both rare and expensive.

Meanwhile the Dirt Trax FX and Stunt Race FX games can be had for $10-15 at times and there were tons of those. Yeah, it does suck to have to cannabalize older SNES games to make one of these, but there is no real way to create your own from scratch due to it being an FX game. No homebrew way to create your own FX chip. I mean, it can probably be implemented with a FPGA but I have zero clue how powerful (and thus expensive) an FPGA one would need. I tried to lookup the hardware in the FXPak but all I could find was that a prototype from 2011 used a Spartan 3 FPGA, no idea if the current carts also use that. Depending on the version they go from $18 to $120, most seem to be $18-40.

As for making it, many have made such a repro in the past. Most of them back then were made with the beta ROM that was floating around for years before the SNES Classic. Issue is with this having been done years ago, most guides are listing parts that are no longer easy to get (mostly the EEPROM) but if you know what you are doing you can use just about any viable EEPROM that's big enough and has the necessary pins.

NTA, but.
Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

>>9596951
>>9596953
Anon who posted that. It's still the original files, but they are preinstalled on an emulated Windows 98 Machine so the game is easy to play

The ISO file is in a folder titled 'Files' along with the Windows 98 drive, and is mounted to the machine so the game can run, but is also there to make it easier to use and explore compared to the format of the original files

To run the machine, run "Launch.bat" in the folder

>qemu-system-i386 -nodefaults -rtc base=localtime -display sdl -L pc-bios -m 256 -machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off -device VGA -device lsi -device sb16 -drive file=Files/w98.qcw -cdrom Files/CB1_DISC.iso -boot c

Its just a one line command that launches the machine with the correct settings, but I obviously get not wanting to run some random batch script and exe, so you can also move the files to your own qemu install and it'll work fine

posts.com:
Hi, I'm currently doing some preparations to do a a study on games inspired by Thief and I need some examples to work with.

So far I have Thief itself, the direct sequels to it, the Dishonored games, Gloomwood, Bioshock Infinite BaS:E2, Delightfyl, Heir Obscure and Neon Struct to work with. These might be plenty but it may prove a good idea to diversify it a bit.

In order to qualify, the games suggested need to fill some of these criteria:
>The game must be playable primarily in first person (this is mandatory, third person games without even the option for first person are excluded. Games like MGS2 may allow first person aiming but would still be excluded since playing most of the game in first person is not an option).
>The game should present stealth as preferable to open combat (though this may not necessarily be the case in practice, the point is that you should at least be lead to think stealth is the better option)
>The game should include some mechanics that resemble Thief's (i.e looting, lockpicking, light and shadow, gadgets, etc. Not all but at least enough to determine similarities)
>The game may but is not required to have a similar world, story or characters to Thief (like how Thief, Dishonered and BaS:E2 all feature a plot in which the player character is betrayed and left for dead once the employers got what they wanted).

It doesn't need to be a perfect match, you just need to be able to draw enough similarities to determine that Thief was the inspiration.

>>9593534
I would remove the Bioshock games because even though Ken Levine and Irrational were involved in Thief during its development, It's very much a System Shock 2 inspired game. Add Filcher to the list as it's clearly inspired by Thief, The Dark Mod is a fan project that is Thief in all but name. If you're going to make a video about games inspired by Thief, you need to mention how the guy who created The Inverted Manse for T2 got hired by Ion Storm because of it, Purah worked on Calendra's Cistern and Calendra's Legacy and got hired by Arkane to work on Dishonored and Prey. Digital Nightfall who is most famous for CoSaS: Mission X ended up working on Dishonored which shares a lot in common with Mission X's tech level and look.

I like the ability to switch blocks mid-chain. It's a lot more active than waiting for your puyo to pop.
>RNG

Frankly if you have another person who regularly likes to play obscure Japanese puzzle games with you you're already winning life so I don't see room for complaint.

A lot of this comes down to taste; IMO Panel de Pon is the best puzzle game ever made but some people are looking for a different experience and there's nothing wrong with that.
Give it a break for a few months and try coming back to it when you're in a different mood, you might be surprised by how much of a difference that makes. I didn't use to like it as much as I do now, it grew on me over time.

>>9593984
I had to shrink Temporal Tantrum MAP24 slightly to avoid breaking the coordinate distance limit. I think one of the Sunder maps also had to be shrunk during the testing process for the same reason.

Basically, if two points on your map are too far apart, it causes overflows in some calculations, causing hit detection errors like melee either missing up close or hitting from ages away, and archviles having infinite range.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Updated rules for A Serious Case of /vr/:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version you get from Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encourged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Please provide a readme listing your name (even if it's anonymous), map name, and sources for any custom content used
>Map must be beatable (duh) and have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ """standards""" (please put some effort into your map)

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an "up-to-date" arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and one-way doors for any closed off rooms/secrets so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties afterwards
>Also keep co-op in mind when balancing encounters, drawn out reinforcement spawners are not fun to wait on
>Hot Starts are not that common in Serious Sam, try making a "lobby" room for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps opened at once and switch between them in the editor)
>Don't forget to make a thumbnail for your level
>Get creative with secrets!

Any other comments or suggestions? I will officially start this next weekend but anyone who's interested can start now if they want.

A level that "necessitate" saves is probably not very good. It either contains heavy RNG elements out of player's control (Like opening a swarm of chaingunners in your face that may kill you or barely damage it based off the rolls) or heavy discrepancy in results based off foreknowledge (Like opening a swarm of chaingunners in your back that can be destroyed by a single rocket if you remember to walk backwards). Or just plain trial-and-error.

It seems that Anbernic silently released a "v2" 353m with different screens from the initial release's, not sure which is better but at least none of the custom firmwares were updated to properly use that new screen yet.
It's a real shame because the 353m is my favorite handheld on hardware side so far: good enough specs for simple Saturn/Dreamcast games, 4:3 screen, supports wi-fi/controller/hdmi and small enough to carry everywhere while still somewhat comfortable to use.

Mine was also a 32GB Memory Card. When started to having this problems I just formatted everything and tried to start all over but didn't work. So I swapped for the 4GB Memory Card I had and everything started working fine. Installed Enso on him and passed all the files from a fresh install to the SD2Vita that I bought and made a backup for this files because if anything goes wrong I have a safety. I also removed the Memory Card and didn't install anything so now I have two backups.
In your case you don't need to do all that >>9574464 if you already Enso your Vita using your Memory Card, you can just copy all the files from your Memory Card to the microSD(after you formatted correctly) and swap the ux0: on the YAMT settings and point to the SD2Vita. After that I recommend you to stop using and remove your Memory Card and just leave him as a backup if you didn't make a backup after you hacked your Vita.
Reminder to only do this if you Enso your Vita.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574813
They designed games around using both screens. Nintendo pushed pretty hard for devs to make use out of the touch screen feature for the lower screen, and this led to quite a lot of square pegs jammed into round holes out of obligation, ergo needless and obnoxious gimmicks foisted on the player. Dawn Of Sorrow comes to mind, the stylus adds exceptionally little to the gameplay, and it actually flows a lot better if you use a romhack which removes the mandatory stylus poking.

Eventually this would be more relaxed, and thus for a lot of games, the second screen didn't serve much more of a purpose other than being something like a map screen, inventory screen, or status screen, which you could manipulate with your stylus if you for whatever reason wanted to take your hands off of the controls.
Those could be pretty convenient and handy in some games, but they also wouldn't have suffered if they only had one screen to work with. Some games were made with the touch screen in mind, such as some drawing games, or Trauma Center, where its application is actually pretty cool and thematically well placed, but most videogames aren't the kind where using a stylus on a screen is a critical or badly needed feature.

So, a gimmick which kind of could be cool for the right kind of games, but which was widely unnecessary. I want to liken it to if the Virtualboy could have been hooked up to a TV to play the games in regular 2D, and then only early games were made with the 3D in mind while most devs just put token efforts in for the 3D and expected you to play it on your TV.

To make this post more retro, the original DS had a slot for GBA slots, of course, so beyond the thing playing DS games, you could play all your favorite GBA games, or pick up later ones for cheaper as the market was moving away from it. Also, some DS games could have some form of interaction with prior GBA titles if two relevant ones were inserted, typically bonuses in a DS sequel to a GBA game.

I think I just realized that 1. I don't play portables much to begin with, 2. I don't like flat handhelds which are most of them, I need some grip, and 3. I think bigger screens are honestly better. This seems kinda small regardless of resolution.

I don't know that I would grab another handheld though. It'd be nice if there was a really decent telescopic controller for android that was lagless and wired, had membrane buttons for face buttons and d-pad instead of snap dome switches or whatever the fuck and had some handles. Only linux based still somewhat cheap handheld I know that has handles is the RGB10 Max 2 if I'm not mistaken but I'm not getting dated shit when they're popping out 20 new handhelds a month.

Yeah it sucks, but here's how I cope on a modern diamond controller setup:
>left face button as A
>bottom face button as B
>right face button as C
>L1 as X

>R1 as Z

>>9592401
There's no physical back button by default, so you basically have 3 options:
>swipe up from the bottom of the touchscreen and tap the "Back" triangle on the bar that appears, or do equivalent "Back" gesture if you selected that option under system settings
>hold whatever button combo you set to activate mouse mode (for me it's L2+R2) down for 3 seconds, then press the B button. In mouse mode, the B button is mapped to "Back", and X is mapped to that thing that lets you view all open apps.
>try this https://retrogamecorps.com/2022/01/16/retroid-pocket-2-starter-guide/#Home
I have yet to find an emulator that doesn't let me map the "pull up menu" function or w/e to R3, so I just do that.

I never see people talk about these on here which is sad since its a super comfy handheld.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596773 (OP)

Doing this is okay if it doesn't look like garbage and the game balance isn't significantly altered. In a 2D game, a wider view of the map or whatever may be a simple convenience or a substantial difficulty reduction. In an old 3D game, smoothing jagged edges tends to emphasize how simplistic the 3D models are, which makes things ugly. In general, you'd have to be stupid to think increasing resolution anachronistically is a good idea, but if you like it then whatever, you might as well do it and make your stupid person's life a little bit less painful. You're probably not ever going to stop being so stupid, after all.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9598151
There is little difference between 2D and 3D. People who run old 3D games at modern native screen resolutions just because the graphical subsystem was made forward compatible, and now reports it to the game as maximum available one in the usual manner, are idiots. Moreover, even when games break, which means no developer has originally tried to run them in higher resolutions even once, they don't see that as a reason to stop, and make patches. That you can do something does not mean you should do that.

Some modern 3D games with complex multi-stage multi-resolution adaptive rendering are probably resolution-agnostic enough, but that's a small fraction of them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9598321
I am talking about old native PC games. Some of them break. Many of them have nonsensical UI in high resolutions. Most of them look like shit in high resolutions. And developers were not stupid or lazy. At the release time there was simply no hardware capable of running those game this way, even for the laughs, so they didn't have to prepare the code or the content for them, even theoretically. If you have a full list of resolutions of a modern video card in game settings, it is not a sign it was meant to be run this way.

Those who run modern ports of games like Quake 2 might not even understand the list of resolutions was static in the original release, and was altered or bypassed by port authors.

>>9586809
I think gamefreak didn't want anyone to feel beholden to any of the adaptation's characters as being "right", encouraging kids to play Pokemon their way, pick their own Pokemon, instead of just being like Ash/Satoshi or manga Red or any other Pokespe protags.
This is why all the theories of what Red's personality is like is missing the point to me. Sure, the fan interpretation of Red as this jaded, serious trainer filled with ennui who travels to the furthest regions of the map to contemplate is a cool idea that makes for cool art. But GF seems to have intended to make Red's party one that doesn't make any presumptions about the player's choices. If its Red from yellow, you know he gets the starters/Pikachu
If your team beating the E4 was one overleveled Blastoise and the rest Pikachu, a level 20 Nidorina, a Graveller, and a few otherunderleveled randos, it was just as canon as someone winning with a team of all Legendaries/ubers
Red's team is all Pokemon you were given (and Snorlax, who you need to encounter) in Yellow. Espeon is there so no one takes any of the three RBY Eeveelutions as the "right" choice , and it shows that Red is such a good trainer his Pokemon evolved though his good friendshion(plus, call it autism, but I thought him having an Espeon was a cheeky reference to Gen 1 not having a night time)
The point was it was 3 years later, so most people could have the Pokemon like Red's team. They aren't necessarily the Pokemon he beat the E4 with, given that other returning trainers from the past changed their teams.

Yes but there's only five HMs. Fly is completely optional and Strength isn't needed until Victory Road (though it unlocks Articuno as well). posts.name: Anonymous

>>9596485
The grades exist to nudge you into playing the game in a way that will be more fun and skillful. It's basically an informal difficulty selection, if you're okay with getting a sub-par rank on every level the game will be easier but less satisfying, just like as if you had played on easy.

Anyway, there are benefits to being considerate about how you attack but I'll grant you don't NEED to do it to beat the game, but even so you need to do things besides button mashing to avoid damage, unless you just tank it all with items but again that's playing on babby mode and an impractical playstyle that's essentially equivalent to skipping the gameplay.

That said, I do kinda get the sense this genre pushes you much harder to learn how to properly defend than it does how to attack. Learning how to deal a lot of damage, combo, or improve your style rank/score is all a lot more optional than learning how to not get hit, and I think it can contribute to these games feeling more button-mashy on a casual level. Something that also bothers me about them is that for all the hype around sick combos, a lot of the enemies can't be meaningfully combo'd. Humanoid bosses in particular can often be stunned, allowing you to wail on them for a bit, but no matter what you do to them during these sections they just sit there: you can't move or manipulate them in any way, all you can do is deal damage. It's lame - I'm not saying you should be able to infinitely combo them, but if they're going to have a "vulnerable" state you can trigger, make them comboable when in that state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597625
You get it right after becoming an adult, and not only does it allow you to progress further, but it unlocks extra exploration potential that you didn't have before. It's the item that really drives home the point that you're in a whole new phase of the game and much more can be done now. The fact that it can hook onto all kinds of surfaces also makes you want to use it everywhere and see where you can go and what you can find.

So, what happened in later games? In MM, you get it relatively late provided you're following the intended path through the game, so while it's just as capable as the OoT Longshot, by that point you've probably explored most places and the game overall just doesn't reward exploration with it quite as much. In TWW you get it REALLY late and it's MUCH more limited in terms of what it can latch on to, so there's close to nothing to do with it past using it in the few places you're meant to use it in the last few dungeons. In TP, while the concept of the Clawshot is cool and doubly so when you get the second one, again, in practice you can only really use it on places you're specifically meant to use it, so exploration potential with it outside of dungeons boils down to finding compatible targets scattered here and there. Likewise with SS, despite the fact you get the double Clawshot much earlier there.

tl;dr it's cool in OoT because you get it at a very appropriate point in the game and the game amply rewards you for trying it out all over the place, and later games clamped down on this aspect in favor of railroading you into using it where they want you to use it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597448
It's an interesting thought exercise, why not have the hookshot in later 3D Zelda titles, or what benefit would adding the hookshot give?

In the case of Twilight Princess and Skyward Sword, instead of a hookshot, you got the "clawshot", which had limited application as it could only pull you to designated markers rather than to given material surfaces.
In Ocarina of Time and Majora's Mask, all the places the hookshot could access were also generally intended, from the right position you could access many spots on a given scene in the game, particularly village rooftops where a secret might be hiding.

Part of changing the hookshot to the clawshot, is that you can no longer rely on commonly placed trees to reach heights.
If you wander around large sprawling maps, the bounds of the playable area usually have large cliff walls which may have trees atop them as decoration. The hookshot would let you get out of bounds too easily, thus the clawshot was introduced to further limit player navigation in a larger world design.

Now, in a game like Breath of the Wild where virtually the entire world map is explorable through air gliding and climbing? A hookshot item wouldn't actually make you able to access any more areas than it previously would, but it might serve to bypass some puzzles or stamina limitations that are in place.
If the hookshot were treated as a tool with durability like bows or rods, it might work; giving the player a chance to quickly reach tricky spots, provide there's a tree or a heavy barrel or something to latch onto.

>>9596872
>brightness is at about 50% now
That sounds like too much. I have my Trinitron at 3 ticks out of 24 or so, while keeping contrast around the middle of the scale. There is some really slight black crushing, but I get almost true blacks this way.
Remember that "brightness" is the black level setting, and "contrast" is the actual maximum brightness. This has been mislabeled for decades, confusing people to no end. Fortunately some manufacturers have started to change this naming convention to better reflect what those settings do, like LG with their last year OLED models.
Now, to do this adjustment properly you'll need to sit in a dark room and bring out a brightness test pattern of sorts, for example the color bars in the 240p Test Suite. Then you turn down the brightness all the way and make your way up until the bar nearest to black gets barely visible (is a bit brighter than black). Similarly for the contrast, you want to avoid near-white highlights getting blown out, so you should be able to differentiate the value that's nearest to white from pure white. Realistically, you'll probably have to settle on some sort of compromise between true blacks and a bit of black crush as no display is perfect. But hey, that ghosting should be gone at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587326
I think it's an issue of standards changing. Nowadays, you'd get an E10+ or T rating from those elements. In the late '90s, however, people seemed to just care less about the degree of violence that appeared in children's media. So, you could get away with a little blood and death, especially if it was subtly put in.

The clearest example of "they could never get away with that today" in an E-rated game I can think of is Mega Man X4. One cutscene has a character slash some others in half as dark red blood splatters everywhere. Even with the whole "they're robots, so it's not really blood" defense, that scene seemingly got the X Collection a T rating alone.

That, but also Sega failing hard while still trying to push the "cool and radical games your parents HATE" angle.
Meanwhile Nintendo were slowly but surely understanding that making games that parents will buy by default for their kids is a goldmine. Hence the steady supply of half-assed Mario games on the DS. That way when some mom needs a present for little Timmy's 8th birthday it's "ah yes the Mario game on the Nintendo, it looks like a cartoon so it's gonna be fine". Then she sees a reassuring "E for fucking normies" rating and that's all she needs to know.
Though the real winners of the ratings wars were the DS shovelware publishers in the mid and late 2000s when they could put out any low-effort game that looked safe enough, got the right rating and would immediately look good to parents.

posts.sub: How come decades later most sword games still miss basic inputs like this?
posts.com:
Spin stick and time your attack to do a spin attack, tilt stick forward and attack to stab, tilt stick right and attack to swing right, tilt stick left to attack to swing left, hold attack to charge, etc. Especially the spin always feels so good and right to do

It's the first thing I test in games with swords and more often than not you can't do anything. Examples are Prince of Persia, Fable, Genji, Crystal Chronicles or even Souls games today

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
It has to do with the speed of the combat and how mobile the character is.

In something like Bayo or Ninja Gaiden you're so much more faster and agile that it wouldn't feel well. Zelda games and Maximo are much slower in combat and you move a lot less. There are sometimes inputs that use the 360 but between 2 different attack buttons, fast enough frame data to make use of pauses (eg A,A vs A,wait,A), and the many ways you can dial up an attack there is no reason to resort to these inputs which as I said are going to feel bad with how fast and agile these newer characters are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
N64 was the "tech demo" phase for a lot of this stuff. Really showing up all of the different ways a character can control in a 3D space, and all of the different things you can do with an analogue stick in gameplay.

After that, we move into the stream-lining phase, where developers are thinking less about what the player "could" do, and thinking more about what most players are going to want, which is simplicity of controls and mechanics. That's either a good or a bad thing, depending on how you view it.

Seems like it was very common for an N64 game to have different movement speeds, climbing, swimming, crawling, ledge grappling, first person view modes, and flight all baked into the design, while a modern game like Elden Ring might not necessarily have even half of those options.

>>9596040
>most playthroughs spend more time moving thru magmoor than progressing in new areas
They really don't, Magmoor is a very direct area with little to stop your progress. Magmoor has extra elevators specifically to speed up backtracking like the one after Thardus and the one in Tallon Overworld.
>artifact hunt is only made more efficient by having done it in an earlier playthrough
You can get the hints to find all the artifacts when you get the Space Jump, early in the game. You don't have to go out of the way at all, it's right where you're already going.
>by knowing there's like 3 artifacts you can get early out of 14.
More like 6 out of 12. These are the artifacts you can get early without even leaving the critical path.
>Chozo (collect while getting x ray visor)
>Wild (collect on way to ice beam)
>Nature (collect on first visit to magmoor, many opportunities to collect later)
>Strength (collect while backtracking for space jump)
>Warrior (collect while backtracking for x ray visor)
>Truth (literally waiting for you in the temple)

>>9595983

The strength of Persona games (unlike mainline SMT ones) comes from the characters being interesting as are their private issues that are laid bare as the plot progresses. There's a lot of sin, decadence, perversion and so on that unravels. That's where the main interest lies.

But the obnoxious rate of random encounters and the typical SMT-type dungeon slogs drag it down because they sap away the momentum of the experience. Later games in the series realized that and put more emphasis on the character stuff and reduced the tedium of dungeon crawling.
It's not that the dungeon crawling is bad conceptually, but in each dungeon (or location equivalent) it FAR outstays it's welcome and becomes a chore. This is true in almost every SMT game, but like I said, in Persona games the interest lies in the characters, while in SMT games it's more about the overall atmosphere of the setting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When it comes to Spider-Man video games from the early 2000's, it's most common to talk about the ones based on Sam Raimi's films, however there was something quite special just before that. Neversoft, at that point most well know for Tony Hawk's Pro Skater, took that engine and simply made what was, at least for its time, the best Spider-Man video game ever made... and they stopped there, focusing mostly on Tony Hawk from that point onwards. However, that wasn't the end of it for good, even though it was 2000, and Sam Raimi's 1st film came out in 2002, Activision made sure to release a lot more.

In that very same year we got a port on Nintendo's Game Boy Color, which was quite different, with areas being connected while Spider-Man leveled up to make progress in them more viable, a lite MetroidVania feel. In 2001 we got ports of Neversoft's original, though they were almost identical, besides making 100% completion a lot easier, since the Quick-Change suit, which used to require 10.000 points to unlock on the Zip-Line training, now required 7.500, still difficult, but much more possible. 2001 also gave us a sequel to Neversoft's original, this time by Vicarious Visions, called Enter Electro, only on PS1.

Activision wasn't satisfied with all of that, and got both Torus Games and Vicarious Visions, which was already working on Enter Electro, pump out a couple of portable titles, one for Game Boy Color and another on Game Boy Advance. Spider-Man 2: The Sinister Six was a sequel for the original Game Boy Color port of Neversoft's original, and it got rid of the more open style in favor of traditional levels. Mysterio's Menace is the one I wonder the most about though, it can be seen as a sort of Spider-Man 3... but is it a sequel to The Sinister Six or Enter Electro? It's portable, but everything it it looks like PS1 assets.

I'd definitely check them out if you can, they're both good in their own way. I'd say that the original one on GBC, while it does somewhat follows the same story as Neversoft's, it plays quite different, not only because of the 2D, but also because there are no levels, just connected areas, making a pseudo open world, and Spider-Man levels up as you progress. It's fun, but flying enemies can be annoying, enemies in general due to how much they respawn, and jumping doesn't feel too good.

Spider-Man 2: The Sinister Six on the other hand, feels quite a lot like Mysterio's Menace, just more basic, as you go from level to level and Spider-Man is the same from beggining to end, no levelling up or acquiring new abilities, either way I love the level design and gameplay, it feels much better than the original, especially jumping, and webbing feels more responsive, even though it's the same button combination, A and then B immediately after it, or B and then A, I don't recall too well, anyways I recommend this one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595717
>In that very same year we got a port on Nintendo's Game Boy Color
OP here, I wrote this in the 1st post of the thread and realized that, out of the 5 installments in this series, if you can call it that, Spider-Man (2000/GBC) was the only one I still hadn't taken the time to play extensively and properly beat, so I decided to play it for a while today. I've decided that I'll beat it, just to complete this series whole, but I've got to say that to me this is the least enjoyable installment. I don't mind the idea of interconnected areas and a pseudo MetroidVania style, but the execution was not ideal at all, for quite a few reasons unfortunately:

1. All areas are nicely condensed and fun to explore except for a single one, the Sewers, which just happen to be where you'll spend most of your time by far, and with no map at all.
2. Flying enemies are the worst to fight against, as Spider-Man's not well equipped to deal with them, so they take a lot of health away, especially the bats... in the Sewers, of course.
3. Control isn't responsive, it takes a second for Spider-Man to respond, and not only that, he keeps too much momentum while on the ground, but his jumping barely goes forward.

I kept playing, giving up, picking it up again, then giving up... until I got sick of it and decided that either I went after a guide or I'd give up on this for good, so I swallowed my pride and used a guide. I feel that the experience is much better now, especially with a map of the Sewers, getting all of the hidden upgrades and taking the best routes so bats don't take away all of your health is ideal too, and almost kind of fun... but overall I can't help but feel that they dropped the ball on this one, both The Sinister Six and Mysterio's Menace were huge improvements.
>Spider-Man most dangerous enemies are bats and seagulls for some reason

Well, just a little update, I've managed to beat it, though I'm not sure if it was a 100% run or not... I've found 2 guides, one from IGN back in the day, and another by Legomondo, I found both to be excellent, but regarding the Defense Upgrade, which are items you find in levels to upgrade your defense to a maximum of 6, there's something odd. Legomondo's guide mentions that Doc Ock's Lab has a Defense Upgrade, but you can level up both your attack and defense to 4 through XP, and then there are 2 Attack Upgrades you can find, which I did, but for defense it mentions a 3rd one in the last level, even though I had already found 2 by then and it doesn't make much sense to reach level 7 even though there isn't even a slot for it, I'm not sure if it's a mistake in the guide or not, but anyways I went into the last bosses completely leveled up in all fronts, so I suppose it counts as a 100% completion, though I'm not sure due to the guide.

Anyways, leaving my 100% completion OCD aside, I want to talk about this installment, a GBC port for one of my favorite video games of all time, which is the PS1 original by Neversoft, of course I didn't expect them to make something as good as that, but I was frustrated by my experience. I've mentioned how cryptic the Sewers are, and how you spend a lot of time lost there and getting swarmed by bats, flying enemies in general feel quite cheap. I still dislike how Spider-Man controls aswell, his jumping and momentum to be more specific, this should be one of the most agile characters in fiction, but he sure doesn't feel like that here. A lot of the concepts just aren't fleshed out enough, like how you pretty much have to grind for XP so you can fully level up Spider-Man... grinding, in a Spider-Man video game, doesn't feel right... also, if they wanted to make a MetroidVania, which I'm down for, they could've at least given players a map...

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597368
I know it all sounds quite negative so far, but it's not all bad though, far from it. One thing that I must stress though... if you're going to play this, do yourself a favor and use a guide, or else you'll probably want to quit as soon as you go to the Sewers for the 1st time, not knowing where to go because everything looks the same, getting attacked from all directions, with tons of bats swarming you and taking away all of your health as you try to find upgrades and fail because they're all hidden in the most cryptic manner possible... it takes a nosedive in quality here so a guide is a must, at least to me. Anyways, I was going to talk about what I liked... and there was lots of it, there's a reason I tried so hard to keep up when I could've just given up, there are lots of qualities here. Well, the 1st thing you'll notice is how it looks and sounds, not only are all sprites and environments well detailed for GBC standards, we've also got some quality tunes and SFX in the OST... and the best part to me is its atmosphere, it's dark, grim, but not edgy and overdone, it feels appropriate for the story told, which is also a good time really.

We have a password system that works well, as intended, and has an atmospheric and moody password screen too which I love... and while I think they messed up a lot of what they went for with this MetroidVania lite style, mostly in execution, some of it does work, when you know how to get all of the upgrades and power Spider-Man up, also some grinding to fully level him up, you feel the difference from early on, how you take enemies down quicker and with ease, when they used to give you trouble. Overall, it can be fun with a guide, combat is satisfying, at least apart from enemies constantly respawning, some level design is good, and atmosphere is perfect... but it can be a frustrating experience, especially for the reasons mentioned earlier here, still, I don't regret my time with it, and I'm glad I played it.

(2/2)

The date scenes are almost too subtle for their own good. The game is amazing at narrative subterfuge, setting up the audience for a love triangle only to hint that there's something more going on. The language implies lovey dovey but the underlying meaning is way more straight forward. Aeris tells Cloud that he doesn't have to pretend to be someone else and that she'd rather meet the real person. Again, like a big sister telling her kid brother to stop pretending to be something he's not. With Tifa's date she tries to say something and backs off. She says "Aeris would be able to say it" or something along those lines. You think that it's an attempt at a love confession but it's really Tifa trying to confront Cloud about his bullshit and Tifa is acknowledging that Aeris is way more assertive than she is. Both girls are trying to use the date to have an intervention and the love triangle gimmick is the smoke and mirrors to disguise it to the player.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think she's more important to Cloud based on his memories of his mother, where his flashbacks of her in Nibelheim are probably his most authentic. This makes the most sense because he never really knew or understood Zack's parents in Gongaga to really appropriate, and even when you do meet them, they act very different from Cloud's memories of his mother. Meanwhile, that Cloud in the flashbacks with his mother is probably the truest version of Cloud we see until the actual reveal come last disc.

She tells him to look for an older woman who can keep him in line, and Aeris does happen to be older, and while that isn't important, I do think the conversation hints more at why he's drawn to Aeris and the way she talks to him, even if that kiddish honesty of hers isn't exactly romantic and more arm's length, which is a luxury Tifa lacks and explains why she can never get to the point with him and can only say nothing at all for a long time.

I like the Cloud and Aeris pairing, but I don't think they were ever romantically drawn to one another. Sephiroth was already insane, he just found a satisfying rationalisation. It's evident even before he goes postal that he's a messed up dude, he ain't a compassionate guy who makes friends, he's a sociopath who exists to be nothing more than a weapon. Learning he was merely military hardware shocked him so much because... it was true, it all clicked. He always knew he was the best of the best, but now he believes that he is inherently perfect and has a literal birthright to godhood. He razes Nibelheim because – as he might describe it – he doesn't feel any sympathy for those ants, they aren't like him, he shouldn't have to care about what they think, and he'd rather the Cetra walk the Earth instead anyway. Sephiroth was previously a war hero before who defended civilians because that's what the mission asked of him; he doesn't have those guidelines anymore—he is on a literal pilgrimage to kill them.

One of the worst things Crisis Core did was try to make Sephiroth a compassionate bloke.

Aiming

Nudging

>>9571254
If you hold the left flipper on the plunge you can go for a super skillshot, which may have a better feed to the flippers. If you don't understand what I'm talking about, here:

http://pinball.org/rules/medievalmadness.html

>>9571268
It's actually called nudging, not tilting. Nudging is nudging, tilting is when you nudge too much.
There's also flipper skills, if you don't want to learn how to nudge you can lengthen your ball times a lot with just aiming and ball control stuff.

>tables have been more or less the same over the last 3 decades
because pinball nearly died its death at the turn of the century, it's safer to stick to the tried and true formula with only small incremental innovations (like colour screens and various other minor gimmickry that don't deviate too much from the traditional pinball experience). The history of pinball is littered with attempts at "innovation" that fell flat on their arses, pic very related.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9578442
>>9578523
Yup, innovations tend to fail.
While some wanted pinballs as wide as pool table, Lawlor created a mini-pinball, with a goose game on the front panel. It was time-based: you had no balls limit, the game would keep giving it back to you until you ran out of time, and you had to complete objectives to get extra time. It was really fun, and it completely failed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9578034
The somewhat rare Jersey Jack Pinball Pirates of the Caribbean pinball machine also has a cannon. You shoot the ball onto the mini-playfield pirate ship that rocks back and forth, and then you load the ball into the cannon. You have to time your shot with the rocking of the ship to get the ball into the hole on the ship on the other side of the playfield. Otherwise it takes multiple shots to get to multiball.

>>9578442
The P3 system by multimorphic is the most innovative thing going on right now.

As far as double wide tables... those exist. They're called widebodies. They're not twice as wide, but they're wider than normal. If they were twice as wide as standard that would be too wide, I think. For reasons that I'm too tired to attempt to explain.

>Can I plug them in?
Why, yes. Especially if you're looking for an alternative way to heat your home.
>Will such old machines have problems if I just plug them back in after many years or not being used?
Probably. But there are just a couple of things to check. Remove the backglass, open the front panel, and find the batteries. Acid is most likely leaking from them straight down on the motherboard.
Also check out the fuses (also in the panel). Just make sure they all work, if needed replace them BUT respect the manual. Don't put slow blow in fast blow and vice versace.
>What would be the best way to sell them?
Keep them.
>Varkon

>>9581298
https://pinside.com/pinball/forum/topic/varkon-club/page/3#post-6628631

Found this post saying he was offered 20k for a restored Varkon (aka a Varkon in very good condition), so 10K for a bad one seems increasingly possible.
The hype thing with sealed videogames is sort of a separate issue from anything going on with pinball. The arcade buying world and the collectible videogame buying world are two different worlds. Even the arcade world and pinball world are kind of different.

There was a pinball auction in California that was covered in the NYT where a bunch of pins were sold to various uninformed people on the internet for way more than they would typically go for, but that's just typical for any auction, I think. But aside from that, new and used pinball prices have been going up, and not in any illusory way.

Part of the reason Varkon is valuable, apart from rarity, is that people like the gameplay and theme. There are a lot of rare games that are not that valuable because people don't care for the gameplay/theme.

The true number of Varkons that exist is probably less than 90 btw, since some of them were converted into arcade (videogame) cabinets. And of course, some of them were probably scrapped.

>>9581778
It's a reasonable choice for number 1, I'd say. It's by Keith Elwin, who was the greatest pinball tournament player for longer than anyone and now is an extremely popular pinball designer. And Godzilla is his most recent game, and it's seemingly universally liked by everyone.

As for what's so good about it:
The playfield is innovative, and the experiment is successful, I'd say. Lots of careful attention paid to geometry. Some interesting stuff that's either never been done before or hasn't been done in this way.
The code is good. Lots of breadth and depth. Not sure what else to say about it, other than that it's full of clever original wrinkles like a lot of other games (particularly Elwin games maybe), but moreso.
People like the theme. As do I.

No
Here's how Pinside's Top 100 works; people buy new Stern machine, out of obligation or guilt or whatever the fuck the owners of new Stern machine (that they paid thousands of dollars for) rank their expensive new toy the best thing ever.
Over time and with normal pinball players giving realistic rankings and pinball owners ranking their newer Stern machines higher the newer Stern machine outranks it, wash and repeat.
12 of the top 20 tables on Pinside were released in the last decade. It's like that bullshit about Black Panther being one of the highest rated movies of all time, it's bullshit bias and agenda.

Chicago Gaming Company:

Cactus Canyon (trickling out slower than anticipated due to production issues or something)

Gottlieb made a modern version of El Dorado called El Dorado City of Gold

Well there was only 7 or so Big Bang Bars and one guy named Gene Cunnigham made 110 more and it was more work than he thought it would be and he ended up losing money.
https://www.polygon.com/features/2017/3/21/14937540/history-of-big-bang-bar-pinball

And a company called Circus Maximus planned to make more of Kingpin, of which there are only 7 or so, but that was a while ago and there's been little sign of progress from them since.

I think making pinball machines is really difficult. And if you're remaking something then you have to get it basically exactly right and can't cut corners. And recreating something sometimes poses other unique challenges which I won't bother to enumerate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9589668
Nudging and tilt bobs (or tilt alarms as you call them) predate flippers. You're talking about something that was introduced before Paul McCartney was born, so it doesn't really make sense to use the word "finally". If the operators don't want people to nudge they can tighten the tilt and/or reduce the number of warnings, and a few do. That's their prerogative.

I don't need to nudge to have a good time, but for a lot of players it enhances their enjoyment of the game, and operators allow nudging because they believe that the increased earnings from nudge-loving players outweighs the cost of extra repairs. Or they simply consider nudging part of the game as well and don't want to eliminate it.

The underlying reality is that pinball machines were designed to steal quarters from kids much like slots from adults, and that kids would use nudging to stay in the game. They added tilt to prevent this and keep the quarter stealing going. When they started making tables for home use, quarter stealing became less of a design focus, but nudging stayed. Personally, I don't really nudge because I think the game is more fun when your skill should solely come from being able to manage the ball with flippers, but I understand why people nudge because its inherent in the nature of a physical game like pinball.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9591112
You seem to be misunderstanding something. Nudging is not something the general public does to machines. It's someone only very specific players do. And Nudging, shifting, or moving the machine *will* cause issues over time. They loosen screws, bolts, and wear out the machine connections at joints. It's a physical movement of the machine afterall. Maybe not cause issues right away, but it will over time.

I've even seen instances where a player nudges too hard and can cause cracks in the glass. Do these people take responsibility? Nope. They just quietly walk away and leave the arcade without saying anything. Now the arcade owner has to pay to replace the glass. And the pinball is now out of service for days or weeks depending on how quickly they replace the glass.

Nudging (or any other "pro" pinball techniques) causes problems over time when a single player does it. Now imagine a pinball machine in a public arcade. It gets played dozens of times a day by many different players. More if it's popular location. It wears out the machine faster. Pins are just pieces of wood and metal after all. It's gonna break eventually if you keep stressing the connection points with movement.

You might be able to get away with it with newer machines but These older pinball machines aren't made anymore and sourcing replacement parts are difficult if something serious breaks. They should be respected and treated with an extra level of care from players if it's an older machine. This isn't the 1980s or 1990s anymore. These machines are old now.


Personally, I'd much rather focus on flipper control than worry about nudging and shifting a machine. If I have to nudge then it means I took a bad shot and misjudged the ball angle. A nudge is like admitting I failed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9593672
>Pinball games are a family of games in which a ball is propelled into a specially designed table where it bounces off various obstacles, scoring points either en route or when it comes to rest. Historically the board was studded with nails called 'pins' and had hollows or pockets which scored points if the ball came to rest in them. Today, pinball is most commonly an arcade game in which the ball is fired into a specially designed cabinet known as a pinball machine, hitting various lights, bumpers, ramps, and other targets depending on its design. The game's object is generally to score as many points as possible by hitting these targets and making various shots with flippers before the ball is lost. Most pinball machines use one ball per turn (except during special multi-ball phases), and the game ends when the ball(s) from the last turn are lost.

>For the nudge, no nudge argument i do think nudging is completely viable
The problem is that the argument is based on:

"I will do whatever it takes to win. I don't care or give af."

Your starting point for the argument is that "you want to win" . So your whole argument is just logical fallacies and justifications on why your questionable actions should be allowed.

But your starting point should be "I should respect the machine and not abuse it".
That should be the starting point for everything. Because if you break it, then you are responsible.

>and if it takes 15 years for the leg to not work anymore and require repairs that is a testament to build quality of machines.

This makes no sense. First of all Most pinball machines are not brand new. Are you going to pay for the damage caused if you "nudge" a machine and (that rare situation happens) the leg gives out? Or if you crack the glass?

Let me also add there is no defined version of "nudging". Movement that might be acceptable to you might be completely understandable to the pinball machine owner.

Other anon said he saw someone lift and slam a pinball machine and called it nudging. Tournaments can get heated too. These pinball machines are Electro-Mechanical machines. Not arcade machines. That means abuse will knock things out of alignment or calibration over time.

>But if the games themselves by design allow you to nudge to a certian degree before it locks up, wouldnt that be encouraging the mechanic as a risk/reward system?

I don't think you understand what "by design" means. Pinball Manufacturers have never promoted moving the machine during play.

Manufacturers noticed people were physical shaking, lifting, and slamming the machine to keep their ball alive. The tilt mechanism was added as a "penalty" for the players.

The tilt mechanism was NOT added as a "challenge" to players. They aren't challenging players to 'see how much they can shake the machine without triggering tilt'.

As someone who has been to plenty of arcades, pinball tournaments, and talked with arcade owners at local places, usually there is a general consensus on what a proper nudge and what is allowed is. Usually there is a clear difference between nudging and straight up abusing the machine. Slapping the sides does not equal picking it up. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597367

>But if the games themselves by design allow you to nudge to a certian degree before it locks up, wouldnt that be encouraging the mechanic as a risk/reward system?

I don't think you understand what "by design" means. Pinball Manufacturers have never promoted moving the machine during play.

Manufacturers noticed people were physical shaking, lifting, and slamming the machine to keep their ball alive. The tilt mechanism was added as a "penalty" for the players.

The tilt mechanism was NOT added as a "challenge" to players. They aren't challenging players to 'see how much they can shake the machine without triggering tilt'.

Giving the player tilt warnings promotes nudging. Some machines replenish players tilt warnings, which promotes nudging.
Example:
Total Nuclear Annihilation gives more tilt warnings for a mystery award.
Jersey Jack's Pirates of the Caribbean lets you gamble tilt warnings to get more in Liar's Dice.
There are probably more I've forgotten.

Also JJP Pirates of the Caribbean has an "escape the locker" hole on the right outlane going to the shooter lane where you can nudge to save your ball. And a crossover return lane.

A lot of machines have unique outlanes that are designed to give you an extra opportunity to save your ball through nudging. Although they do occasionally give you your ball back without nudging, the designers clearly intended them to be used with nudging.

Centaur, Skateball, Full Throttle, Alien, Wheel of Fortune, etcetera.

I find Sonic 2 to be easier than Sonic 1 if you're just going from start to finish, since the level design it more suited for speed, and you have the spin dash, as long as you use it wisely and press down to roll in slopes you should be fine... if you're going for 100% though, I find it much harder, as the special stages can be much more punishing than Sonic 1, at least you get more attempts at the emeralds, but you'll probably fail them more often too, also the last level is quite tough.

Anyways, good luck!

P.S. If you play Sonic 2 (8bit) then go for the Master System version and stay far away from the Game Gear one, but for Sonic 1 (8bit) either of them is fine.

>>9595614
Not sure if the Wii VC version had this problem, but the original Sonic 3 & Knuckles has some content that you can only see/hear by playing Sonic 3 standalone (the biggest difference being the final boss) and then locking on to Sonic & Knuckles to finish the rest of that save file, but compilations routinely mess this up and made them separate save systems entirely. So in an emulator, you can finish Sonic 3, rename the save file to whatever your Sonic 3 & Knuckles game file is called, and then continue the game from where you left off. OR, you could play Sonic 3 & Knuckles through Sonic 3 Angel Island Revisited, which I can't recommend enough. It gives you options to restore Sonic 3 content, QoL improvements, gives you widescreen like the mobile ports, has extensive mod support, and best of all, it brilliantly uses the original ROM. Sonic 2 also has a A.I.R. equivalent called Sonic 2 Community's Cut, so 1 and CD are probably happening sooner or later.

>old media is DYING

SO CHANGE THR FUCKING BATTERIES!! I hate zoomers and poorfags who say shit like this. There isn't a single problem that could occur with cartridge games that can't be repaired so long as you aren't a fucking retard and leave it out in the rain or something.

>Battery dies
Replace it
>Sticker gets messed up
You can get a replacement if you really care
>Data on the chip gets corrupted
It can be rewritten, and you can also replace the chip if you really need to
>save ram dies (problem on games like Sonic 3)
You can replace it with a more modern save ram that will outlive your grandchildren even if you and your kin all play the game daily for the rest of your lives
>Cartridge shelll cracks
This can be repaired, and if it's really fucking bad you can replace the shell
>Capacitor goes bad
Replace it with a new one
Pins get messed up
They can be repaired, or worst case scenario you can remove all of the chips and repopulate them to a new board and Jo you don't need a donor cart for this since you can buy brand new PCB's
>Battery leaks and damages the board
This shouldn't happen if you take care of your games in the first place and also because these batteries last for literal decades, but if it does happen then you can try to clean it or if it's really bad you can repopulate the chips to another board.

So long as you're not a FUCKING RETARD these games will last until long after you and I have left this earth. There wasn’t much to Metroid before Super-Metroid, and even then it was a dead franchise until Retro came along with the idea for Metroid-Prime to reinvent it. F-Zero also never was reinvented, just “zomg new graphics” a couple times and then graphics plateaued so they let it die, and Nintento took the mechanics for the canned F-Zero ZX to make Mario/Kart 8 instead. After Mario-Kart’s success, we’ll never get a new F-Zero.

Any franchise that doesn’t get reinvented from Nintento is doomed to die.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597671
I like blurry pixels because it's what I remember the games looking like when I was a kid. I'm either the oldest zoomer or the youngest millennial but I had a small CRT in my bedroom while growing up and I had a SNES, N64, and Gamecube hooked up to it through composite and I remember what it looked like pretty well because I played on that thing until I moved out of my parents house. I remember when he got our LCD TV and I was excited to play some games on it because it was a bigger screen so I hooked up my N64 and played Pokemon Stadium and it looked so fucking terrible that I never wanted to play old games on it.

I do actually play on a modern TV but I connect all of my consoles through a RetroTink 5X and I adjust the settings per console to find the ideal look. There's a lot of shitty CRT filters in RetroArch but I think the custom options that exist on the RetroTink are actually really good and can produce a nice image. I'm excited to see where they go with this in the future with the 4K model because it's really pretty convincing. My friend has a PVM and I've even fooled him with pictures of it.

Raw pixels are better than nothing and I put up with it for a long time before picking up the RetroTink but it's not my preference.

>The combat is shit. And it's basically a Nintendo collectathon (albeit a quality one), whether you like this kind of game is up to you.
killing most "enemies" in the game is just pointless. it's like that in many Ninty games, but especially here. enemies don't even feel like enemies, they're more like obstacles, designed to slow you down or even just to be a platform / whatever. the game is a fake run'n'gun, I know it's not supposed to be Contra or Mega Man X, but c'mon. you get all those abilities and weapons, but there's barely any satisfaction in using them to kill enemies. to me, a puzzle/action with shit action is just a half of a good game.
rest of the game is just typical Nintendo stuff, solving puzzles and finding all the secrets, which is basically a collectathon. it's great if you like this sort of game, I've just played many more games like that before Super Metroid, so it didn't really feel like anything new to me. the puzzles are the best part of the game, IMO.
as for "one interconnected map" concept, it's not really non-linear (unless you want to break the "rules" of the game, like speedrunners do). in fact, it's pretty damn linear, on my playthrough there was almost always just 1 real way to go.
I never called SM bad, I'm just saying that it's not underrated at all, in fact it's a bit overrated today as it has been jerked into the status of literally best 2D game ever, some kino wino domino masterpiece, with people ready to write fucking books about how great it is (like they do about most 1st part Nintendo titles). everyone has simply grown completely uncritical of this game, exaggerating its greatness because muh Nintendo, and completely ignoring other games that took same concepts.

>>9592516
I have been considering this game anew and I want to hear what you guys have to say about the following fault I’ve found with the game: the bosses are often painfully unintuitive for new players. They feature weaknesses that are hard to guess and hard to tell when you’re doing it right versus wrong. For instance, phantoon does his special attack when you super missile him. A new player unfamiliar with his patterns will have a tough time linking that attack to a super missile hitting him and as such will probably stumble through the fight. The worst offender is draygon with the grapple zapple. If you don’t use the grapple against it the fight is really really hard for a new player. Finally, Ridley is practically immune to missiles, taking 180 to die from them as opposed to 20 charge shots, making him not only wall players using regular boss strategies (use missiles and supers) but also doesn’t give any indication that charge shots are doing more (other than noticing the faster color change on him). These bosses seem like an area where the game fails to communicate to the player, unlike the entire rest of the game, which is filled with thoughtful touches.

Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596120
It's too easy.
I think that the game is a lot more fun to play on Luck Mode, because it makes you weak as fuck early on and you need to be very methodical and careful to not get raped immediately, but you do catch up with the game as you go, and by the time you reach the end of the upside down castle you're not struggling anywhere.

The GBA and DS games added Hard Modes, which are nice, though those need to be unlocked. AOS played fresh on Hard Mode (not carrying over stuff from a run), I think is the most fun way to play it.

>>9596154
There's some left. The Clocktower is kind of AIDS, but it's brief and you don't have to go back there again after you've gotten through. The upside down castle is missable/skippable, but honestly it's worth at least getting as far as seeing it for a bit, just for the novelty. The game loses steam a bit once you get there, but the pace also winds up a lot and it's quite fast to explore as you already have all abilities as you get there.

>>9596234
I do think that there's some fun in trying out random OP shit, in a HOMM3 kind of way, but that kind of comes at odds with challenge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9598179
Oh yeah, I remember starting out and thinking "Portable classrooms? What kind of school is this?" It made you earn the permanent buildings as if you were building a school in some underfunded shithole. And the passage of time was so slow, I accidentally blew my budget on parent/teacher conferences the first time I played and was in debt for so long, I gave up even though I would have eventually made the money back. It was just so boring to sit there and look at it.

The worst thing a tycoon game can be is boring when idle. If your tycoon game isn't interesting to look at when you're not building, why is it even a tycoon game?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9598190
seriously, sometimes i blow tons of time in RCT just watching the coasters run. It's all so smooth and nice to watch stuff you made flow well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9598197
Sometimes I join servers just to look around. Good idle activity is the secret to why so many of these building games are so good. RCT is the king of it, since you can follow a guest for hours as they go about their day at your park. Zoo Tycoon has tons of stuff happening, too, with zoo keepers feeding animals and people walking around and doing shit with almost the same depth as RCT. But even Sim City is good with it, you can sit back and watch zones fill with construction, and you can watch traffic flow. If the player isn't actively building, interesting shit NEEDS to be happening. It's vital game design.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dual Analogs are cool but the design of the analog stick housing is really bad. The analog mechanism uses a thin, not keyed (basically around) metal post and there's no reinforcement at all around the slot inside the stick cap. What this means is that the stick can can rotate freely after the slot loosens even slightly which makes it feels weird to use, and inevitably the force of moving it will cause the slot to crack apart and make the analog stick go completely loose. Literally every single Dual Analog I've found in the wild has broken stick caps like that.

IT's really easy to fix thankfully. Disassemble, glue the slot back together, reinforce it with something, and put some glue in the hole to help keep it from rotating when you put it back on the post. I have two Dual Analog controllers and I had to fix both of them like this.

>>9591490
Other way around really. I'd be more inclined to believe that only early adopters of the PS1 even knew about the digital controller. Sony pushed the analog controller very hard after its introduction. System bundles always had the Analog controller after a point and they stopped selling individual digital controllers. The entire reason why the Dual Analog was missing rumble outside of Japan was because they wanted to get it to market faster and cheaper.

I basically ignored it except for being a less weird looking and slightly less cheap feeling second controller than the one with a Saturn style d-pad we had and thought it was weird until I somehow realized you could press the analog button and use it to trail brake in Gran Turismo without eating shit, and thankfully that usage ignores how bad the d-pad and face buttons were. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9593442
That's the Dual Analog controller, all the differences of note
>Longer handles (Longer than Dualshocks)
>Concave plastic sticks
>R2/L2 buttons have ridges on them in addition to being bigger than they are on the digital controller (same size as Dualshocks)
>No rumble motors outside of japan (if you have donors you can actually solder in appropriate motors into the burger/euro versions and they work fine)
>Analog button actually selects between 3 modes: Digital (Off), Analog (Red light, what you're familiar with), and a flight mode (Green Light, which basically just inverts the sticks to emulate flight sticks)
>The Analog mode can't be automatically set by games unlike Dualshocks you have to do it yourself.

It's a neat controller although the flight mode is ultimately kind of pointless when games could just invert it for you if they bother to have the option. It would actually be pretty convenient if you could use it to invert the analog sticks whenever you wanted but when it's in flight mode it ceases to be recognized as a Dualshock and does nothing unless the game supports the standard PS1 flight sticks such as >>9591962

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594753
I see this take being posted a lot more often in recent years, and I couldn't disagree more. I know it's a matter of taste, and if you don't enjoy something I do then that's fine really, but I can't help but feel that a lot of people don't give Sonic a fair enough shot and end up missing out on experiences they might've loved otherwise. When it comes to Sonic, the reason you run into things and get hit is because, well, you're going fast and, depending on how quick your reflexes are, you might not be able to react to things in time, it's something that varies from player to player and that's fine, but I can see why some would go through this and assume that it's all memorization...

Still, all video games require us to memorize sections we're having trouble with, and we're not supposed to be good at a video game as soon as we pick it up, it'd be shallow otherwise, if you could just run and win, then no one would've cared about Sonic, it's a franchise that rewards you for sticking around. One more thing that can help, is that Sonic's vulnerable when he's just running, but not when he's jumping... or rolling into a ball, always make sure to press down in slopes, not only do you gain speed, but you also protect yourself. Also, if you prefer something like Mario, then I can't recommend Sonic's 8bit library enough, they're a lot more Mario like than the original Genesis installments, Sonic 1 is excellent on both Game Gear and Master System, if you go for Sonic 2 then always pick the Master System version, otherwise it's too punishing, but if you go for Sonic Chaos then go for Game Gear, otherwise it's too simple. I hope you can give Sonic another fair shot, but if you prefer not to then that's your choice, but trust me, they're excellent video games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592669
In each level, you drive around the area with your tank, finding dungeons to enter on foot.
Most of those dungeons are optional, but important so you can upgrade your gun. Although you can very well just find a good place to grind your gun, go back&forth, and then be on your way.
One of the dungeons in each level has a boss which gives you an upgrade for the tank (like a new weapon or hover or driving on walls etc), necessary to unlock the path to the next level, and so on.

You can strafe by holding the bomb button.
Try to always have your gun max'd out before a boss, I know it's not easy. Some higher gun levels are actually shittier than earlier ones too because of poor hit detection. If all else fails, find a good spot to spam grenade on a boss.

Other protips: some of the levels loop on themselves, or have shortcuts that teleport you to another area. It makes some levels more confusing than they should be (level 2 is actually the worse)
You only have 3 lives, 4 continues. Infinite continues in the JPN version. It's actually pretty hard to beat the game in 4 continues, you have to know where to go, I only did it after beating the JPN version.
At some point once you get a certain upgrade, you'll find there is nowhere to go with the tank. You have to think Metroid and backtrack to an earlier level.
