posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590638
Honestly play both (specifically OG Metafight for >>9590696 reasons). Blaster Master Zero gives you the outward impression of being a stright remake of the first game with its opening area and returning enemies, but then it throws a curveball and the series turns out to be a brilliantly subverted Metafight sequel.
...Oh, you wanted to dabble in the older sequels? Don't. The series was passed around Z-teams and didn't go anywhere until Zero, so you're better off ignoring them. The PlayStation game may be worth checking out if you want some context for a few story elements in Zero 2&3, and MAYBE try the GBC one if you just want more BM-otherwise, do yourself a favor and avoid the Western-made shovelware.

its varies quite a lot depending on the size/weight of what youre ordering and where you are. I live in the uk and we now have a free trade agreement with japan so we dont have to pay any customs or import fees outside of the postage unless its over a certain value. If youre in the EU I think you have to pay 20% vat for the import + extra servicing fees. Most recent thing I have ordered was a set of 13 ps2 games and the postage for those is 4000 yen or 30 usd. I ordered a white ps2 recently the shipping for that was 4500 yen or 25 dollars. I dont remember the exact value but i ordered a set of two fat ps3s and the postage ended up being something crazy like 120 dollars but it still worked out cheaper than buying locally as one was a backwards compatible model. Anime figures on average are about 25 dollars postage when i order those. Although it used to be cheaper before the russia ukraine bullshit. Japan post has a postage service called small air parcel which was very cheap and i think i used to be able to get figures shipped for like 10-15 dollars but they cant fly here anymore because they used to go over ukraine. These are all airmail and it will arrive within a week you can get seamail which is cheaper but takes like 2 months or something so ive never tried it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597718
IMHO, not really. Groundbreaking (and game breaking, fucking Buggerfall man...) for the time, but nowadays it's seriously quite meh. The randomly generated quests won't keep you invested into it for too long once you're done with the major questlines, they've added them back in Skyrim, so if you've played that -you already know what the drill is. Dungeons were quite complex, but you could easily navigate your way around them and get out fast by following the same rule you would when trapped in a real life maze - just turn left whenever possible and you'll be out before you know it. Robbing stores was kinda fun though as was climbing. Game's free nowadays anyway, so there's nothing stopping you from trying it, but I wouldn't recommend it. Think TES peaked at Morrowind personally.

You're just mad that looking in the mirror reminds you of the character creation menu.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9593632
can OoT be underrated? i think deep down everyone knows it's revolutionary and how innovative it is, even if they cannot copy-paste a list of everything.

-deku stick and arrows can be lit on fire to transfer it to burnable obstacles
-playable instrument allowed for a multitude of different castable spells.
-ztargeting that allows you to lock onto enemies and strafe them, recenter the camera, and peer around corners all without an additional analog stick.
-Navi is a interactive guidance system as a character.
-a rideable mount to get around the huge hubworld that you can wield a bow and arrow while advancing forward, teleportation between important locations, and shortcuts at various junctures.
-you could see locations far off in the distance like death mountain from hyrule field or kakariko village from death mountain and go there.
-face buttons you could reassign items to.
-the menu system is an intuitive cube you rotate to the information and your equipment is visibly attached and detached from your portrait.
-choreographed combat where when you see an enemy guarding it's blocking, and when it lowers its guard it's vulnerable.
-you automatically jump when walking off of ledges with momentum, drop and jump to grabs, all without the need for another button.
-the context sensitive action button literally everything uses, in OoT it told you simple words what would happen should you press it.
-attention to detail such as shadows that rotated around the character in relation to light sources, water that reflected objects, and rooms being blanketed in darkness when enemies sap light from the room to hurl as weapons.

Nah, it was fine, unless you're opposed on-principle to the idea of Fox going around on-foot. Never understood the bitching about the controls, they were basically identical to GC Metroid Prime; if people could learn to play that, they could learn to play this. The Landmaster feels significantly more responsive than, say, the Scorpion from Halo. The Arwing is indeed slower and floatier than in 64, but that's kind of a necessity in the free roam levels where you're expected to navigate actual level geometry, as opposed to 64's all-range levels consisting of flying over empty plains.

The worst that can be said about Assault is that it's too short, completely linear, and the ground missions all have the same objective. Still easily better than Adventures and anything that came afterward.

>>9587369
There's semconflicting info in the manual and opening text. In her manual profile, it says that she's the "only survivor of her doomed home planet of Cerinia" and "roams the galaxy in search of answers." In the opening text, she "searches for the truth of her parents' death." Either way, she picks up a distress call in a small world in the Lylat system and investigates, the implication being that she has a feeling it's related to her troubles. You can infer that Cerinia was outside Lylat, she was orphaned recently, Andross had something to do with it and lured her, she dresses in a manner that's not unusual on her home planet, and that ship she used to board the Great Fox was probably how she initially arrived on the planet....
....and since absolutely none of that was followed through in the slightest, the Japanese version apparently cuts any and all mention of Cerinia or her parents, and doesn't even subtitle the line suggesting she might've recognized Andross, so she in the Japanese version has even less nuggets of back-story and is a totally random scantily clad blue adventurer.

>>9597848
>Japan has been having a hard time
You seem to be unaware but Korea's electronics manufacturing is entirely dependent on Japan for ultra high tech components. Even 3 years after being removed from the trusted trade partners list they're still struggling to become unreliant on Japan. Moon boasted a while back that they were able to find replacements with European companies but what he didn't reveal that it was actually the European branches of the same Japanese companies that they were doing business with before, which means that they're still completely reliant on Japan.

Japan has largely moved away from producing consumer electronics except for a few brands who continue to make simple home goods like Panasonic and Hitachi, but a lot of those products are only for the domestic Japanese market. Japan instead has chosen to focus on patents and ultra high tech like supplying over half the global supply of robots for manufacturing. Companies with bad business decisions like Sony got bit in the ass by that decision for trying to compete against the same countries that they moved their manufacturing to.

>>9590467
Tiger-Heli is probably the best beginner shmup there is as it forces you to learn all of the basics to complete it without dying, and also has very forgiving checkpoints. Ideally, you want to practice sections without dying though, as you can just brute-force through sections with dying.

It's just a very basic game that beginners would probably find too primitive/boring, and the main flaw is just that the terrain and enemies are so limited that it's hard to actually know/memorize which section you're at because it all flows together.

>>9590227
All depend on what you are looking for.

Any shmup can be your first it really, depend on the dedication you want to poor on it, even more true when nowdays you have training tools, adjustable auto fire,rewind and save states which make the training way more efficient and short.

Also be aware that some games can be average to hard to 1CC but very hard to insane 2ALL ( 2nd Loop), some Psikyo games are like this for example.

Now for the recommendation I try to give you some easily emulated or game available on steam or ACA :
Relatively easy.
Dariusburst AC : depend on the route but it mostly easy/mild hard at best for an 1CC)
Akai Katana got released last month it's a mild difficulty cave with a lot of thing to learn from.
Area 88 is fun arcade game you may learn movement and placement, learning curve is kind of flat but expect a small pick at level 5. give the snes/sfc version a try too.

Normal
R-type leo is kind of the same you may also learn some stuff about force and option (harder at level 4).
Fighting Hawk is close to Area 88 but as a verti. not too hard not too easy
Metal Black is between the 2 but you won't learn that much from as the game is weird AF.
some others weird shmup ; fun but wont learn much from them.
Xexex mild 1CC on the japanese version. (2all is another story)
X-Multiply is slightly harder to 1CC but at least you won't have a burnout dealing with it 2ALL even if it's hard.

Mild hard
Game Tengoku is cute nice and fun and you will learn tons of shit and tricks, but 2ALL is on another story, way too hard for it own good.
Dragon Spirit is old but it one of my favorite games ever, it come from a time where you needed a separate button to shoot sol enemies. Maybe a little bit long and learning curve can be a bitch.
Outzone depend on the version and weapon management can be a nice game to pick.

Also most Psikyo and Cave games 1CC can be put here.

>>9592041
>Why was this game so damn weird?
Because the only source material for the cartoon they were basing it off of was the first 5 episodes. The whole bit about Shredder having that ray gun in the end comes directly from that. The gun was supposed to be able to turn Splinter back to a human in the cartoon as well, but was was destroyed by him to save the turtles. The game serves as an alternate retelling of the first season of the cartoon without the Krang or Dimension X stuff, and an ending that doesn't enforce the status quo.

Level 3 is supposed to be your recovery/restocking level, and it's the last time you get easy chances at renewable pizza and recovering lost turtles. The building near spawn is for healing up who you have left. Then you punch through to the south, and cross the foot-bridge south-east of the building there. Enter the doorway on the right, rescue lost turtle. Exit, enter again for each turtle you need. Once you have a full crew, you can go grind scrolls in the building just west and north. Also has a full pizza in the basement if you need healing. Plus if you make sure Ralph and Mike are the two that go down, Leo and Don can survive just fine.
You'll be glad you have the scrolls when you start to deal with the really hard levels.

Considering Saturn was a failure outside of Japan, I'd say Dreamcast.

No one in the USA cared about the Saturn in the 1990s. It was a joke to a majority of people. If you went into a game store, it was either Nintendo 64 or Playstation 1 that dominated store shelves. Most stores didn't have a Sega Saturn display section. And if they did, it was tiny and shoved near the clearance section. Saturn was overpriced and just a terrible selection of games in the USA. No Sonic either. How stupid. No one cared about Saturn. And it just died and wasn't even remember by most kids.

Dreamcast at least had hype. I remember retailer's carrying the system and hyping it up. Selling special edition versions like the Black Dreamcast and other colors. It was a big deal. Too bad about Sega going bankrupt (because apparently Saturn drained their finances too much), but Dreamcast sold 3x the amount of the Saturn in half the amount of time. Much more memorable games too. Crazy Taxi, Soul Caliber, Sonic adventure, etc. If only Sega didn't run their business into the ground I'm sure Dreamcast would have done respectable for itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9589170
If you had to choose between the Saturn or the Dreamcast for playing games on the original hardware than the clear choice is the Saturn. The Dreamcast is a great system, but the majority of its best games have been ported or re-released on other platforms, whereas the majority of the Saturn's best games are exclusive to the console.

Saturn consoles are still fairly cheap as well, you can get a jap import model with a controller, a memory cart, and sometimes a game or three for around $100 shipped. Spend another $50 on a PseudoSaturn cartridge and you'll be able to play burned games. Alternately you can get an ODE fairly cheaply (from around $140 to around $220, depending on the model).

The Dreamcast can play burned games natively since the copy protection was cracked over 20 years ago, but since the DC supported GD-ROMs (essentially CDs that could store 1GB of data compared to the 700MB you could get out of a CD-ROM) a significant portion of the games on the system have to have data trimmed to make them fit on a CD-R. This usually means stuff like video being heavily downsampled, audio being downsampled, or sometimes audio/video being removed completely. The ODE situation on the Dreamcast is kinda fucked as well (they exist, but availability can be a pain in the dick if you don't want to buy the more expensive model).

Either console will have a solid selection of arcade ports, RPGs, and action games. Neither console had a ton of lightgun games - the Saturn basically has a couple of solid Virtua Cop games, a mediocre port of House of the Dead, and the typical Maximum Force/Area 51 combo (plus a few not stellar others), meanwhile the Dreamcast has a great port of House of the Dead 2 and Confidential Mission (plus a couple more gun sections in other games). Columbine happened in early '99 and basically tanked any US releases of lightgun games for a few years, so the DC got almost none.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597751
>The Dreamcast was a failed hail mary from it inception.

It's pretty sad, because the Dreamcast was basically designed to fix every single problem that developers had with the Saturn:

> The multi-processor architecture on the Saturn is a pain in the ass to code for and port games from other consoles to
The Dreamcast was built with a single powerful CPU
> We needed to utilize the RAM cart to get the best performance because of the low amount of memory, a peripheral that wasn't even released outside of Japan
The Dreamcast shipped with 16MB of RAM, an insane amount for a console in 1999
> It's difficult to get high quality 3D graphics out of the console
The Dreamcast shipped with a powerful GPU, 8MB of VRAM for high quality textures, and hardware antialiasing (meaning AA was essentially "free")
> People were turned off by the Saturn's high pricetag at launch
The Dreamcast launched at half the price of the Saturn, and two thirds the expected price of the PS2
> Coding games for the Saturn is difficult due to the low quality official documentation
Sega made a point to have extensive and widely available hardware documentation for developers
> Porting games from the PC to the Saturn is difficult to impossible
The Dreamcast shipped with WindowsCE support to make porting games from the PC to the console easier (if developers chose to utilize it)
> Coding online multiplayer for Saturn games wasn't worth the time and money spent due to low sales of the Netlink (mostly due to its high cost)
Every Dreamcast launched with a 33.6k or 56.6k dialup modem, and support for a broadband adaptor
> Supporting 3 or more players in games is a waste of time due to the low sales of the multi-tap
The Dreamcast shipped with four controller ports

Pretty much the only steps backward from the Saturn were no onboard save storage, and the controller (losing the 3x2 arcade layout in exchange for a 2x2 diamond as well as using only a single analog stick).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9597795
>The Dreamcast launched at half the price of the Saturn, and two thirds the expected price of the PS2

This was probably Sega's only mistake.

Sega should have never sold the Dreamcast at loss (sell it for less than it costs to make it). They would never win against Sony who also sells at a loss but has money to burn.

Nintendo NEVER sells at a loss. Nintendo always sells their consoles for a profit. Even if its a small profit. Sega should have done the same as Nintendo. They can't fight Sony the same way they fought Nintendo.

Plus Sega was actually not in a good financial position before launching the Dreamcast. The failure of the Sega Saturn hurt Sega and bloodied them. Sega didn't actually have the cash reserves to fully support a new system. Maybe if Sega had several more years to recover. But of course that wasn't happening. The Playstation 2 was coming.

So Sega took out loans and went into deep debt to make the Dreamcast happen. The only way to pay the loans back was if the Dreamcast sold huge numbers. Like Sega Genesis numbers.

I'm trying to think of reasons. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595170
3D platformers were just one of the best design spaces for what was available at the time. People were excited by exploring 3D worlds which have a lot more exploration possibility then 2D worlds. Platformers have a lot of vertical gameplay which lends itself to exploration. And with the limited graphical scale cartoony style had a lot of potential. Shooting (golden eye) and melee combat (ocarina) were decent at their very best and wonky most of the time.

The 5th generation was about creating interesting spectable using the new super-graphics but clunky controls. And the three approaches that dominated it were reflect this
*3D platformer: Fast real time movement that focused on being cute and colorful while exploring
*Survival horror: Slow real time movement that focused on realistic and dark. Less exploration but more tightly designed
*JRPG: Turn based or very slow real time that focused on epic adventure and game length.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2016/12/feature_the_making_of_metal_gear_solid_the_twin_snakes

Meanwhile in Japan, there was a team of individuals at Konami - handpicked and overseen by Hideo Kojima - responsible for the key creative output. "Most of the actual decisions were made in Japan, including any new ideas to add/update, reviews, and approvals." Toledo reveals. "We at Silicon Knights generally did the grunt work, while the team in Japan did the meat of the assets. We generally modified their assets to enhance visual quality and clean up and optimize code." Traver adds an analogy to describe how the partnership worked. "Konami had made it very clear earlier on that we at Silicon Knights were creating the VCR to play their movie."

This new imagining of the visuals also extended to the cutscenes. Where characters previously had static faces and eyes made of pixels, on GameCube they had full animation and lip synching for dialogue - all of which was re-recorded with most of the original cast. In the position of director was Japanese filmmaker Ryuhei Kitamura, known for his high octane action films. As Kitamura explains, it was Hideo Kojima's love of films that landed him the job. "Hideo came and watched my first feature Versus and loved it and we became very good friends. When I was making Azumi he asked me if I'd be interested in doing cutscenes for Twin Snakes. How could I resist?!"

The in-game cutscenes weren't merely graphical updates either. They added new action set pieces, showcased great feats of strength from characters and emphasised elements like bullet-time. Although fans have debated this creative direction through the years, it was very much the wish of Kojima to explore new territory. "Hideo told me to go completely new and different." Kitamura reveals. "He gave me total freedom because he knew that I was a big fan of his work so that I would never do something he wouldn't want. He also loved my second movie Alive

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9570560
>My question is, why shouldn't I play the original NES? Is it really that bad? And which even are the original ones?
The programmer Nasir, was unfamiliar with RPGs and barely managed to code the game together. The classic Final Fantasies were always a little buggy, but typically you'd have to really go out of your way to notice - the first Final Fantasy is obviously roughest since it was Nasir's first attempt. Elemental weapons don't work as they should, a good fourth or third of the spells weren't playtested, stat bugs, etc. The game got more or less fully bugfixed in the WonderSwan Color remake and its PlayStation port. Rereleases from GBA onward go further and are based on the latter's easy mode, changing up a lot of the game mechanics to make it even easier. They don't really represent the original experience too well.
As far as the second game goes, reception is generally the opposite. A lot of people didn't care in retrospect about the experimental gameplay, so you see more people vouching for GBA-onward rereleases of II. GBA also adds a postgame, but like almost all the rerelease-padded content, it's not very good, in this case being a remix of the final dungeons. You might want to try GBA or PR if original just doesn't click with you.
Beyond that, III is more enjoyable in either 2D form for myriad reasons, and nearly any version of IV is decent (except WSC/GBA, & 3D TAY is horrible). The rest should be played in original form where possible, give or take a translation/restoration patch.
>I mostly care about translation accuracy
The ChaosRush one is the one you want then, preferably with an enhancement that makes the game play more like rereleases / as intended. Default is probably better since Chaos Edition looks like it makes a bit too much guesswork with DND equivalents. If you play a rerelease, note the script has been somewhat expanded in WSC and again on GBA to account for increased text space. WSC fantranslations are incomplete unfortunately.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
People obsess over the little bugs in FF1 but in truth, bugs in 8-bit RPGs are the norm. Probably a combination of having less experience from what came before, less playstesting, and limited RAM and ROM. FF1, FF2, DQ2, DQ3, Metal Max, Mother, Pokémon, etc etc they all have their share of bugs and the funny thing is, very often you'll stumble on similar bugs or bugs caused by similar things.
Does that make the games bad? Well, objectively, they are flaws, but in the majority of cases they're things one will rarely stumble upon by himself or that don't really matter, at best a small nuisance. 8-bit jRPGs are still my favourite kinds of RPGs

While my list may seem short, I'm sure if people obsessed over more 8-bit RPGs as they did with those, we'd find more bugs everywhere. Meaning those are only known and obsessed upon because they are in the most famous games. The FF1 situation is similar to younger people listing the bugs in pokémon B/R because they want to "prove" by A+B that their soulless Po-litically-correct-mon is superior.

>>9573706
>The programmer Nasir, was unfamiliar with RPGs and barely managed to code the game together.

and yet the game was leagues above Square's previous RPG, Cleopatra no Mahou, and just before that he also programmed Rad Racer.
It's also worth noting that in terms of scope, in terms of number of mechanics, spells, classes, enemies, etc etc FF1 was unprecedented for a console RPG. FF1 was 3x the scope of DQ2, which was THE reference (and main influence) at the time, and only DQ3 would reach the same scope 3 months later.

After FF1, Nasir's work visa was no longer valid. Did Square find a new programmer? No. They moved the development team in the US for a while just so Nasir could work with them.
That should tell you how precious he was to them, and again, bugs in 8-bit RPGs were a norm, and in hindsight, the bugs in FF1 are nothing compared to what you can find in DQ3 (the infamous bug with creating too many party members at the inn which completly breaks the game)

>>9570560
>I mostly care about translation accuracy
FYI, these would be the versions you want to play if that's most important to you:
FF1: Chaos Rush (seconding Default, maybe w/original font patch)
FF2: Chaos Rush
FF3: Pixel Remaster; Chaos Rush's was made before PR and it's a tweaked script port of the revamped DS remake that doesn't fully work, dunno if he/she ever plans to update it.
FF4: PSP has the least wrong with it, but DS would be better if prose was less flowery. No real equivalent for SFC but I guess the closest would be Fixed Evisceration (Namingway Edition is more popular but takes fanfic-y liberties).
FF5: This is the one I'm not too sure about. The GBA version might be best overall, but it feels like Square was being vindictive at times about their official PSX versions of 4&5 being outshined at the time by unofficial SFC translation hacks, so they overlocalized it to the point a few key scenes almost feel like parody. You'll see some defend these edits, but it's clear in reality that they have trash taste. SFC original does have a GBA script port. The base fan translation is showing its age, but you could try checking out Spooniest's "Legend of the Crystals" addendum instead. It fixes a number of problems with the original fan translation, and the latest 2.x update incorporates parts of the GBA version that aren't embarrassingly dated (to my knowledge).
FF6: hairy_hen's retranslation is undoubtedly the most accurate option. Just be aware that you can't turn off the bugfixes and stuff, but that goes for every relocalization hack, even the GBA script port (which alone is still more accurate than the original).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not to say there aren't subpar versions of these games (because there clearly are) but I find it a little fascinating how easily you can tell the agerange/experience of people who suggest certain versions of the classic Final Fantasies. You can divide it into at least three major phases:
>1987-2003 (Famicom-PlayStation): The Square Era. The company respects its legacy catelog and may do some QoL here and there for re-releases but otherwise leaves the experience relatively untouched. For oldies.
>2004-2020 (Advance+): The Square Enix Era. The merger fundamentally shifts priorities and the company no longer sees the classic games in the same light, suddenly perceiving flaws that must in some way be "corrected" in each successive re-release, effectively pulling a Lucas except replace George with mostly random employees. For newbies.
>2021-present (Pixel Remaster): The Postmodern Era. In the wake of the abject failure of the later re-releases, the company receives word that pixels are "in" and commissions a new coat of paint that outwardly goes back to the tried-and-true basics, but upon closer inspection carries over much of what was done to these games in the previous phase, creating hodgepodge versions that don't strictly belong in either phase. For plebs.

>>9584116
Pretty much all 2D FF ports and remakes have been done by Tose, all the way from FFIV PSX to FFVI PR. WSC introduced a lot of changes to FF and FFII that have carried over to all the subsequent versions, and WSC/PSX both completely changed the graphics for current tech like the PSP and mobile phone releases. SNES games just got direct ports to PSX (which suck) because the display format didn't change significantly between those two consoles. Similar reasoning as to why FFVII-IX weren't touched until the last decade, since they could just straight up be played on a PS2 and PS3.

>>9574214
>Thief and BM are the worst physical and magic-based classes, respectively, but you can get hella good mileage out of Monk if you dedicate yourself to grinding.
Thief was hit the hardest in terms of bugs. It's supposed to make up for its weaknesses in sheer luck and agility, but in practice, it's a total paperweight. It becomes better after class change, but that's not saying much when even a fourth-rate Knight w/Icebrand can out-damage a first-rate Ninja w/Katana. But in a bugfixed/remade version? Thief becomes MUCH more viable and almost feels like another class entirely, and Ninja's access to Haste and bugfixed Temper means it's not to be underestimated. Meanwhile, both the Black and White Mages are simply too damn squishy even accounting for bugfixed Int, and taking full advantage of them by decking out their magic slots makes them lowkey the most expensive classes to maintain, so they're hardly worth wasting slots. This ironically makes the default party of the NES/MSX version the best beginner-friendly one in the long run since it has the most reasonable variety; in the original/bugged version, Thief is just too much of a drag in the long run and you're better off replacing it with literally anything else. I dunno why remakes then swap out Monk and Red Mage for White and Black Mages. That's just a straight-up worse setup even in those versions. All the good magic can be learned by Red Wizard, and physical stats are way more important in this game, so it's a nobrainer. Overall, Warrior>Monk>Red>Ninja>Black/White>Thief.

>>9585613
> All the good magic can be learned by Red Wizard
Due to the way the magic scaling works in remakes, doubling in base power at thresholds of 20, 30, 40, 50 etc., the Red Wizard will have what amounts to base level magic power of the NES/PSX versions still when nearing level 50, not breaking 30 until or after that point, while the Black Mage has gotten 1~2 extra layers of damage at any one point in the game. Then there's the overpowered healing items, standard MP system and other changes that change the game in a major way.
There simply is no need for Black Magic outside of Haste and Temper in the later versions due them being based on the easy version of PSX. The abundant healing items and overinflated leveling speed means that you're not in danger of being whittled down, and any damage your fighters deal is enough to one shot enemies, while your MP dependent mages will be either barely missing out on kills. For bosses you Temper/Haste/Giants glove the Master and one or two shot the bosses, save for Chaos. Even the Lich is handled easily with Diaga spells from your White Mage.
Personally I go for
>NES/PSX: Knight, Master, Red Wizard, White Wizard
>Later Versions: Knight, Master, Ninja, White Wizard.

Ps. please format you posts, it's really hard to read a wall of text with no breaks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Time Splitters (only on Game Cube)
>Time Splitters 2
>Quake 3 : Arena
>Half-Life : Decay (only on Playstation 2)
>Serious Sam : The First Encounter
>Serious Sam : The Second Encounter
>Metroid Prime (only on Gamecube )
>Medal Of Honor : Frontline
>Unreal Championship
>007 : Nightfire
These were the good games which looked modern and were on PS2, XBox, and Gamecube between 2000 to 2002. Certainly worthy competitors in the market (Metroid Prime maybe not aiming for the exact same market segments), but with the edge of splitscreen and online multiplayer, together with overall being a good game with good presentation, marketed strongly, I don't think there's any wonder why it did quite well for itself.

However, people forget that if you wanted a first person shooter on XBox, that Halo was the ONLY one there until 2002, where you would see a couple of middling games until roughly about a year after Halo's launch, where you'd finally see some good games on the console like Unreal Championship, Serious Sam, Timesplitters 2, etc. Thus, Halo had basically an unchallenged share of the market for a time, where its reputation did it well against middling or nonexistent competition on its home turf, letting it establish itself pretty well, with the PC port not coming until 2003, and which wasn't quite great, so if you were interested in Halo you probably wanted to get it on XBox. This would help set the stage for Halo 2 in 2004, which was a real barnburner, selling over two million units on its release day, and which had a popular and enduring multiplayer scene.

tl;dr it was a good game which in some aspects had limited competition, with a series which kept growing in popularity as it went.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You know what Halo was? The quintessential 7/10 that was released at the perfect time and on the perfect console. The only reason anybody continues to talk about this series like the second coming of the jeebus is because, for a brief window of time, it was the only semi decent game on a largely terrible platform -- and it was marketed by one of the biggest, most influential companies on earth. The game itself is painfully derivative; its sole contribution to the genre was making analog control scheme standard for console shooters. In every other way, Halo ranges from mediocre to outright bad. Let's talk about some of Halo's "innovations"...
>game begins with superhuman cyborg badass running away from every enemy he sees while human soldiers defend him, until he can find a general that gives him a weapon (and says he doesn't keep it loaded, even though he does. because uhhh... no reason at all.)
>first real level drops you into a wide open environment with absolutely 100% fuck all nothing to find, where you'll skirmish with a handful of small enemy groups and then drive a buggy and then it's over

I think some of that comes from how the people who were just seriously into those games kept playing with each other once everyone else moves on, and the skill and knowledge of the game just concentrates in that smaller and more focused playerbase, as you're pitting the dedicated players against each other and they keep getting better.

Then, when a later newbie outsider takes interest in the game and tries it out, they find themselves stomped by the elite old guard who know game and meta like the back of their own hand and have 10+ years of well reinforced neural pathways, which can make these scenes feel impenetrable. Less apparent in games where there's other game modes besides deathmatch and team play, but it's still easy to feel like a fifth wheel in co-op multiplayer when the experienced players do all the work while you're still trying to figure out what you're doing and how to approach it.

It's not really so much the competitive, and the old competitive players from the height of the game may very well still be able to trounce the rest of the playerbase once they readapt to the game or/and derust their gaming skills, depending on where they went in life.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9579129
Grenade buttons weren't invented by Halo, but that doesn't mean that Halo didn't have a part in popularizing them. There's many cases where an aspect may get credited to something even if it wasn't actually the first game to ever do it, often it's because the game in question did it both in a good way, and the game sold well, making a good and visible example.
You can look at FPS as a whole for this, Wolfenstein 3D gets touted as the original first person shooter, but it isn't true, aside from iD themselves having made the Catacomb 3D and Hovertank 3D games back when they were still the Gamer's Edge division at Softdisk magazine, there's simple first person shooting games on arcades and even computers and consoles which predate that.

What Wolfenstein 3D does though is put the player in a 3D space with textured walls, where they can move freely, and there's a focus on FAST gameplay, no fiddling with any stats or inventory, it's just shooting the gnutzis, avoiding getting shot as much as you can, while managing your resources and finding the exit to the next level (which may involve up to two different keys), finding treasures and secrets confers benefits of extra lives and putting yourself on your own personal scoreboard.
The gameplay is perhaps slightly too simple (hence being quickly overshadowed by Doom, which hits a fantastic balance), but more importantly it was a fast and widely available first person action game unlike any other.
Thus, it gets credit for assembling this into the very base formula that came to change the world.

Of course, nothing Halo does actually REVOLUTIONIZES anything, huge hits had done it all before, and it didn't reinvent grenade buttons, games like Team Fortress Classic already implemented those well, but it was one of those games which made the concept really take off because it was a fairly big commercial and critical hit which implemented the mechanic well and made it a prominent feature of its popular multiplayer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Halo was average at best. People thought it was amazing because they were young and impressionable when Microsoft's marketing machine kicked into overdrive to move units on the x-box, since it was the 'flagship' title.

I've played many hundreds of hours of those games in a social setting (split screen, LAN, XBL and Xlink). Why did I play so many hours on an average game? Because it was a good way to catch up with friends and let off some steam, since it geared as a party game, so people that weren't that skilled could still join and have fun.

In the group of course there were three fanboys that played even more than me, their explanations as to why it's "so awesome":

>it doesn't do everything well, but it puts together different things well
Perhaps the most honest answer, he can't point at anything in particular, he's played enough games to know Halo didn't invent much new, but likes that there isn't any major annoyances in integrating all the different systems (from controls to game balance).

>the AI
This is because the levels were heavily scripted, so for example someone might say "wow that elite took cover behind this corner there when it's shields were down, that was clever" - players don't know that Bungie just added these places into the terrain. Another level where you're on the beach, where grunts and jackals "fall back" because you shot the elite, there is actually a zone on the beach where they can retreat to baked into the game.

>the short time to kill, recharging shields/health
Honestly, I was never a huge fan of this concept but I think Halo 1 nailed it the best with the longer recharge time and and needing to venture to health packs. When they shortened the timer and fast regenerating health, for Halo 2 and beyond, it made the dynamic even worse (encourages people to just hide out of the action).

>>9579915
I don't care much for regenerating health, I find it's usually a crutch for not wanting to do better level design, but grenades being a quick button instead of its own defined weapon to manually switch to is just fucking practical and makes grenades more viable and fun. With a button I can just make a grenade throw and it automatically returns me to my weapon afterwards, that's smooth and I don't need to come to a halt, you can make the gameplay faster for it, and in return increase the challenge for the player to match their abilities.

In Half-Life, I find myself not using hand grenades all that often because that requires that I stop shooting what I'm using now and switching to another weapon, manually throwing it, and then switching back. Because of that, in the heat of combat I basically never ever use them because I don't want to let up the pressure, whereas I gladly use the grenade launcher altfire because it's very conveniently attached to my machinegun (and it also detonates on impact).
The role I end up using them for (aside from maybe demolition or setting off tripmines from around a corner), is if I have the drop on an enemy, in which case one or two grenades are my opening before lay down fire. This is useful, but more occasionally, and the grunts tend to avoid it, which in itself isn't bad, it's nice that different enemies require differing tactics and approaches, that's good, but it makes the already limited grenades still more limited.

If I instead chuck one with a dedicated press, I could maybe use it when in actual combat with the grunts, if nothing else to flush them out or suppress them.

>>9573635
Bungie's Halo franchise had a significant impact on the video game industry for several reasons:

Revolutionary gameplay: Halo's gameplay was a revolutionary combination of fast-paced first-person shooter action and vehicular combat, with a strong emphasis on strategic thinking and teamwork. This new type of gameplay was a major departure from traditional shooters, and it quickly became popular among players and critics alike.

Story and world-building: Halo's story and world-building were also highly praised, with the game's rich lore and deep universe drawing players in and keeping them engaged. The game's story was complex and well-written, with a strong emphasis on the themes of humanity, sacrifice, and the struggle against an alien threat.

Multiplayer: Halo's multiplayer was also a major contributing factor to its success. The game's smooth, responsive multiplayer gameplay and robust matchmaking system made it easy for players to connect with others and play together online. The game's multiplayer mode was widely regarded as one of the best of its generation, and it helped to popularize online multiplayer gaming.

Xbox: Halo was a launch title for the Xbox and it was one of the main reasons why the console was successful. Halo helped to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market, and it helped to expand the audience for console gaming.

Innovation: Halo was innovative in many aspects, such as the use of the shield system to regenerate health, the use of vehicles, and the AI of the enemies. These features were not present in most of the first-person shooters at the time and they helped to set Halo apart from its competitors.

Overall, Halo's combination of revolutionary gameplay, engaging story, and exciting multiplayer helped to establish it as a landmark title in the video game industry and solidified its place as one of the most iconic franchises in gaming history.

Bungie's Halo: Combat Evolved had a huge impact on the industry for several reasons:

- Gameplay: Halo's gameplay was praised for its smooth and responsive controls, as well as its diverse and challenging AI. This made it stand out among other first-person shooters of its time and set the standard for future console shooters.

- Storyline: Halo's storyline was praised for its depth, complexity and cinematic qualities. It was one of the first console games to have a fully-realized, cinematic story experience.

- Multi-player: Halo's multi-player component was also a major contributing factor to its success. The game's multi-player mode, which allowed players to compete against each other over a network, was a major breakthrough for console gaming, as it helped to establish the console as a viable platform for online gaming.

- Technical achievement: Halo was also a technical achievement for its time, featuring impressive graphics and a large, open-ended level design, which helped to create a sense of immersion and freedom for the player.

- The Halo franchise has also been a major contributor to the Xbox brand, Halo being one of the Xbox's most successful franchises and helping to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market.

All in all, the combination of these factors made Halo a groundbreaking game that set new standards for the industry and helped to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9593316
>>9593773
Lord, you don't even understand that I wasn't advocating their use, and simply nudged to look at their inception.

Let's get back to mid-90s, when ability to play a video or an animation in a window didn't mean you could automatically do the same in full screen.

https://archive.org/details/CDROMToday11Jan1995/page/n59/mode/2up

Stretching a single bitmap to a different size was not an instant operation, and doing it many times a second could easily exceed both CPU performance and memory bandwidth with all the pixel copying. (Even today a scroll through resized photos in a viewer can be noticeably slower than a scroll through the same files at original size.) Software had to rely on system-provided, driver-provided, or its own optimized scaler functions to be as fast as possible. It often wasn't even proper nearest neighbor scaling, but a block-of-pixel-based assembly routines hard-coded for the specific CPU memory bus width and cache size (or, later, MMX, or, later, SSE), possibly with some fixed dithering.

It is funny that with all the retro circlejerk it's hard to find the video of just a regular video player being used on real hardware. Unique texturing algorithm choices on the first generation of 3D accelerators can give you an idea of speed-optimized scaling results:

https://www.vintage3d.org/images/AT3D/gallery.php
https://www.vintage3d.org/gallery/permedia.php
etc.

Due to hardware limitations, it was still often not possible to do something the straightforward way. Games could use interlaced 120 line video clips to fill the 240 line image because CD-ROM and system performance couldn't handle bigger data streams. When Windows 3.1 media player was told to play the video in full screen, it simply grabbed the video card exclusively, changed the video mode to a smaller and faster one, and bypassed the Windows GUI altogether.

Fast scalers, rotozoomers, and the rest were also important demoscene effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595074
So-called 2D (GUI) accelerators and hardware overlay boards (often with a genlock for external TV signal) that could stretch your bitmaps for you had already existed as a niche professional market. However, it was finally understood that all that multimedia and interactive media often needed to use it on every frame. Video cards began to have dedicated hardware for that (and also began to consume YUV video frames, freeing the CPU from converting each one to RGB after decoding). See how review mentions that the card can stretch the buffer with bilinear filtering (!):

https://archive.org/details/pcworld151unse/page/227/mode/1up

Wow, we have that tiny worse-than-VCD clip playing in full screen with smooth pixels! Of course, bilinear filtering also gives you lots of blur, especially when dealing small bitmaps like NES output buffer.

The problem with hardware stretching is that it is done in hardware. The overlay variant specifically happens after the whole frame buffer is consumed and processed, and treats it like a green screen over which the given image is overlaid (duh). Software couldn't guess how good was the quality of scaling, as computer couldn't even technically get the result back from the screen. Still, it was important to offload as much as possible to the hardware to save CPU performance for the main tasks. Composite and S-Video outputs that later appeared often on regular video cards worked in the same black box manner. How exactly TV picture was generated from output buffer (the whole screen or active accelerated surface) was defined by chip makers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9595076
In addition, a fixed set of desktop resolutions everyone used (640×480, 800×600, 1024×768) did not align well with console screen resolutions. Today you can integer scale that 256×244 to any ratio almost up to 10×. Back then, unless the emulator was a dedicated full screen application, you had to compromise by cutting part of the picture or making it smaller than the desktop (not so great when your monitor was already small). The other alternative was to zoom 2× or 3x, then slightly resize the output, and have either smudged or uneven pixels.

And of course, the aspect ratio of TV console output pixels is not 1:1, so to correct the almost-square picture to (more or less physically correct) 4:3, you had to stretch with different coefficients vertically and horizontally.

On the one hand, hardware scaling on a specific system with a specific hardware using specific resolution could be a blurry mess, a blocky mess, or a combination of both. On the other hand, emulators had to use it in most cases, and had to be prepared for that. The idea of all those 2× and 3x filters was to implement fast enhancing upscale (instead of the regular pixel doubled or pixel tripled copy) that would help contrast lines (e. g. text on screen) to survive the uncontrollable external stretching. They compensated for the less than stellar processing down the path.

Then after a couple of years, a couple of processor and video card families, and a couple of DirectX versions letting software interact with hardware through new APIs, it all slowly stopped being relevant. The rest is just wanking. First, some developers decided that all the increased computing power should better be spent on magical algorithms that could convert pixel art into high resolution graphics (they couldn't). Second, clueless users who discovered scaling options mistook them for some important improvements that could be used on their own.

If you have all the modern CPU and GPU performance to produce something that looks similar enough to the original thing, you never need the filters that were used in year 1999 to solve year 1999 problems.

So what you can do? First, use the talk page to list your doubts:
— Single low quality source.
— Source doesn't actually mention those model numbers.
— Direct TV output was not an option, no “PAL models” are known to exist. That said, it had nothing to do with NTSC either, the refresh rate was probably chosen to be similar enough to port existing games without recalculation of all timing constants.
— It would require a big technical mess to use a different refresh rate for the screen (another independent oscillator, wire speed buffering, and so on).
— Emulators have zero support for such a thing.

>The Myth: The average person swallows eight spiders per year. Fear not. In a 1993 PC Professional article, columnist Lisa Holst wrote about the ubiquitous lists of "facts" that were circulating via e-mail and how readily they were accepted as truthful by gullible recipients. To demonstrate her point, Holst offered her own made-up list of equally ridiculous "facts," among which was the statistic cited above about the average person's swallowing eight spiders per year, which she took from a collection of common misbeliefs printed in a 1954 book on insect folklore. Then maybe while the group is staying the night among the underworld dwarves or Eblan's ninjas, he chats with some locals and gains basic training in some other clever mechanical or magical tool that he could use well thanks to his unusual set of strengths. Like, I don't know, a programmable doll the dwarves have that can carry a bomb to an enemy, or a small set of unique spells (kinda like Edge's spells) that he learns from some old scroll you find somewhere that nobody else can read because it uses an outmoded writing style that only fruity royal types and dusty scholars like Tellah ever learn (and Tellah's gone then). Maybe at some point he discovers he has a bit of aptitude for a certain kind of battle strategy and so can arrange for the party to surprise enemies and get first strike more often, or even to disrupt enemies with a trick in the middle of a battle and give the party a round's worth of free turns right then. He could just build up various odd abilities here and there, gradually becoming more useful and gaining confidence.

Then during the endgame he finally achieves his final form when you go deep into a lunar cavern and discover a set of ancient mech suits that are driven via piano keyboards or something, and nobody can get them to do anything except musical Edward, so now he's a cyborg with a shoulder-mounted cannon and he's as sturdy as Cecil. And also the ghost of Anna occasionally aids him in battle and she's naked and looks really pretty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: When you visit the land of the summoned monsters, he makes a pact with one of them that allows it to live in his body so that it can explore the outside world, in exchange for its services in battle. This could be knitted into the plot and given emotional weight in any number of ways. (Maybe it's a bit tragic, like what happens to the king and queen of Eblan.) From then on he has whatever set of physical and magical powers the designer of this change chooses to give him via the monster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9592376
>gamecube version
original, 60fps, best graphics, 4:3, you can force 16:9 on dolphin but it doesn't scale 2D elements well(dialogue boxes are super large) and at times you can see unloaded models or black backgrounds/sky boxes outside of the 4:3 area.
>ps2 version
nobody cases since its japanese only, but tl;dr it has worse visuals and 30fps because ps2 sucks ass, it did add little bit of new optional content though
>ps3 version
HD port, fixed the 16:9 issues and 2d elements scales better, since its based on the ps2 port graphics are worse, it runs 30fps, but it has little bit more content, one optional dungeon is now longer and has unique boss fight, theres more artes, more costumes, theres new OP song and one more anime-cutsecene. They nerfed some things like that one dragon in earth temple dropping lots of gald, and you have to do something to get into getting Kratos route. Theres also japanese voices available for voiced skits.
>PC port
pretty much barebones port of ps3 version, minus the sequel. Its super mediocre port and modders couldn't bring it to 60fps so you might as well emulate the gamecube version.
>""""remastered"""" port for modern consoles
another lazy port of the PC version, it runs 30fps and there is zero new content added, and it still lacks the sequel

So if you have gamecube or can emulate it, and if you're not scared of 4:3, then play that. Otherwise play it on whatever other consoles you have, its the same shit.

Well, it is true. There's no material on Earth that can stop or deflect a narrow projection of dense mass or energy moving at high speed unless it's dense itself. Whatever magic spandex armor Inafune came up with for MMZ is just too silly for me.

By 1984 there were various fastloaders you could choose from, effectively making it even faster than the Apple II floppy depending on which fastloader you're getting.
>it was also really expensive because it had to contain it's own processor and RAM since the computer itself couldn't handle it
It was thanks to the dumb decision by the Commodore people to make it backwards compatible with the Commodore PET. On the bright side, having its own CPU and RAM meant it could easily be hacked to load the disks faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560340
In fact a bad PSU will blow up the RAM before it harms any other components in the computer. The RAM chips have small, dense dies and are very easily damaged by overvoltage while the main chips like VIC-II et al have relatively large, coarse dies that can take a fair bit of abuse. So the RAM is basically like a crumple zone in a car frame; it will get toasted first and provide a warning of imminent PSU failure.

If you happen to find a C64 with bad RAM it's more often than not a PSU fault and an indication that you'd better throw that PSU away at once (occasionally you'll come across a machine with Micron RAM chips which do a fine job of self-destructing with no help needed).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562815
in fact the very earliest 6502s from 1975-76 were 8 um. over time MOS managed to shrink this some. the VIC-II as anon said was 5 um but also had substantially more transistors than a 6502. by the time C64 was in development, they had two main production lines running. the first was the NMOS line that couldn't do anything smaller than 5 um. there was another line that did 3 um HMOS. the large process nodes that VIC-II and SID used were outdated by the time Reagan was president but they were there and there was no point in not using them as the production line was there and the VIC-II and SID wouldn't benefit from die shrink as much as a CPU or RAM. also MOS had years of experience with the older large node NMOS process and the initial production run of VIC-II/SID in 1982 got something like 80% yields. by the time they'd moved to the plastic-shelled R2 VIC-II in early '83 it would have been better than 95% yields.

during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.

yes those large node processes were outdated, but since Commodore only made chips for in-house use and didn't have to be concerned with consumer demand as Intel and Motorola did, they didn't necessarily need to be aggressive about adopting the latest tech.

posts.com:

Bil Herd claimed they had difficulty doping the wafers properly and applied too much dopant for the die size--this resulted in excessive conductivity and was visible on the die as "creeping crud" (his words). For contrast here's a section of an 8086 die. The transistors are dark purple from the dopant coating. What presumably happened with those TED chips was excess dopant oozing out onto the substrate.

As an EE, I say this has to be case-by-case. Throwing heat sinks around without reason can do more harm than good e.g. if they fall off and short the PCB.
Quality of IC manufacture, PCB/circuit design and tolerance to other part variation/failure are a few factors affecting IC life. True it is a waste of time for most instances, but a stoopid looking heat sink in the right place could help if a chip is poorly made, or could be subject to abnormal operating conditions. Any actual benefit, if any, will depend on the context

Could be a subreddit he's pasting from. It is still better to run stuff not too hot; a chip's data sheet will state its maximum operating temperature and for the 5 um NMOS chips Commodore used this was about 70C. In typical operating use a VIC-II will probably reach about 40C but a sink will knock several degrees off of that. Keep in mind that 5 um was already an outdated process node by the early 80s and most chips had moved to smaller sizes by then. The C64C has 2 um chips that only get a little warm when running and are significantly more reliable. Only the 8580 SID still gets a bit hot as it retains a separate 9V line to operate its analog filters.

>>9562853
HMOS is simply the name Intel came up with for the 3.5 um depletion mode process they developed for the 8086 and licensed to other manufacturers (initially tested on a DRAM chip prior to the 8086's introduction). It's really just NMOS with a smaller die size, nothing special about it. Using Intel's terminology, HMOS I was the original 3.5 um process, HMOS II was 2 um, and HMOS III was 1 um.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The 8080 had a 6 micrometer die. Larger die sizes get hotter as more power is needed, and the power requirement goes up the more transistors are in there. So while a 6502 and its 3,527 transistors were not a big problem at 5 micrometers, the VIC-II had roughly 13,000 on the same die size.

Shrinking the die but using the same transistor count will reduce power use and heat output.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587507
Heat is the main issue. A hot running IC will die early due to electron migration of the aluminum interconnects causing an open circuit. Most chips have a stated maximum temperature on their data sheet and the closer you get to the threshold the more likely it will experience an internal failure from electron migration.

It's usually one of those two things--overheating or overvoltage that kills an IC.

If you want to know specifically why heat is bad for ICs, two reasons.

1. It can cause the dopant molecules on the die to shift around. If they drift out of place, the transistor ceases to be a transistor. This doesn't happen immediately, but years of exposure to high operating temperatures can do the trick.
2. It can cause an interconnect to fail from electron migration.

>>9596624
No heat isn't everything. Conventional knowledge (not horse shit here) is *the packaging* is the most likely element to fail, which can happen in a few ways (moisture absorbtion, cracking from shock, distortion causing stress on the silicon being a major cause etc). Epoxies used to package ICs vary in composition and, importantly, the fillers used to cheapen their manufacture, improve elasticity etc. Ceramic is better but rare.

Heat rates a very distant second. It affects electromigration RATE, but EM will eventually kill any chip that doesn't die from something else first at room temp. Heat can aid package decay but is unlikely - the epoxies used are less susceptible to heat than previously mentioned problems.

Like packaging composition, each process node can involve different proprietary methods and will have different limitations. It is difficult to nail down generic IC properties and limitations but silicon itself has an unusual conductance/temp curve that imposes a relatively low practical temp limit with current technologies (this may well change). Silicon at 30 degrees and 300 degrees F have roughly the same conductivity and between here is lower - a safe zone for the silicon itself, ignoring all else. Although the resistance actually starts dropping at 200 deg and temp can be much harder to control at this point. Too low and thermal stress can shatter the core, too high is MUCH worse because...
1) cheap packaging will more likely distort / fail.
2) lower resistance will likely cause excessive load on power AND signal circuits connected to it, meaning the system will simply start to break down e.g corrupting data. This state may be just temporary, unlike...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 3) results of interrelated effects of dielectric breakdown, thermal runaway (lower resistance draws more current, creating more heat, lowering resistance, drawing even more current and so on)

>>9597785
Heat output is a balance of more factors than this. Here's a few starters:

1) Fab processes vary between companies, even for the same size. This means they vary in efficiency too. Heat is a waste product usually from electrical resistance/impedance and more efficient processes have less waste heat.

2) there is more to a cpu than the process it is made on. E.g Gold interconnects are expensive but far less resistive than copper which itself outclasses aluminum. What do the CPUs you are comparing use?

3) your cpu does not have 100% of its circuits being used at any time, but generally the more being used, and the more often in a certain space of time, the greater the current draw and resultant waste heat. So, yes frequency as well as architecture are specifically responsible for generating heat too.

How many circuits can be used at once is an architectural matter, nothing to do with the process node itself. I believe operating frequency is better determined by working backwards from this (how fast can I run this chip while maintaining electrical and thermal stability) due to variances. This is why overclocking is a thing. A manufacturer should have a good idea of what this should be in the design phase though.

I have made a musical discovery regarding an old favorite: The "drugstore" (weapons, items etc) music from Earthbound is modeled on "Maxwell's Silver Hammer", by The Beatles. Although they are musically distinct, they have a clear similarity:

-Both melodies are these happy, mid-tempo, plodding but slightly subversive things.
-The pitch goes jauntily up-and-down in both cases.
-the ending of each "verse" is unmistakably the same. Try singing "sure that she was dead" to the ending of the drugstore music before it repeats again (the drugstore take adds two beats after this)
-the developers were clearly into the Beatles, per an early in-game Onett joke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590329
Those things like flavour text when saving help immersion and world building, although admittedly they come from Dragon Quest and devs just copied everything DQ did.

As for msg and battle speed: they are pretty fast by JRPG standard of the time.

Although again one thing to consider is that those were made with Japanese text in mind, which uses about 2x less characters, and when translating to other languages and they would almost never increase text speed to compensate for having more characters (very often it's not that simple and would take to reprogram the entire setup altogether just to slightly increase the speed). This also affects battle speed when you have to wait for the text to end for the next action to take place.

With that said IIRC in Earthbound you could set the speed so fast I didn't even have time to read WTF was going, so I'm not sure what you're complaining about or I'm mixing my memory up with another game (I have played many)

FF1 (and DQ2) do have really fast text and battle speed, even in their US versions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
CPU does more damage based on system setting from 1 to 8.
CPU blocks more often based on system setting.
CPU is slightly easier in rounds 2 and 3.
The CPU is more active and intelligent based on where you are in the game ladder and system setting:
Opponent 1, round 1 is the easiest.
Opponent 1, rounds 2 and 3 are slightly more difficult.
Opponents 2-3 are a little harder than previous.
Opponent 4-7 is significantly harder than previous.
Opponent 8 is a little harder than previous.
Opponent 9-11 slightly easier than opponent 8 (unless you have a bad match-up against Claw)
Opponent 12 if Dictator is both harder and easier due to more predictable A.I. but Dictator does a lot of damage in this form.
Opponent 12 if Gouki is massively harder and does insane damage on higher system settings.
The A.I. changes behaviors slightly when their health is low and this behavior is based on the personality of the character such as Ken doing some 2-3 hit combos into DP you'd rarely or never see him do at full health.
The A.I. has certain character specific strategies such as Ryu doing cr. lk against Boxer rushes or Chun-li head-stomping Guile.
The A.I. will occasionally do a "crazy" combo regardless of difficulty setting to show players the potential of the gameplay, but this is very rare. Maybe 1/256 matches?
North American "Super Turbo" arcade releases are supposedly bugged and always set to level 8 regardless of system setting. (I need to test this properly, I play mostly on X)
Street Fighter Collection release on PS1 significantly reduces CPU difficulty. Level 8 on the PS1 is easier than Level 4 of the arcade release. Gouki in particular seems much easier to defeat.
Dreamcast release seems to have arcade difficulty (?)
The CPU does in fact cheat and read inputs btw. Guile and Dee-Jay break the charge time limit and Gief clearly reads inputs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are three game endings.
1. Basic ending, no staff roll.
2. Basic ending, staff roll with characters fighting. Achieved by clearing the game without losing a match.
3. Basic ending, staff roll with special character artworks + class photo. Achieved by beating the game without losing a round. Double K.O. does not count as a round lost.

System setting does not affect ending.

Gouki appears in all endings. Even if you beat his ass without losing a round.

>>9596578
Overall, the CPU is easier in rounds 2 and 3.
However, there is an exception in the very first round you play of the game where the CPU is very easy to defeat. This is to allow the player to get their bearings and adjust to the controls. It also makes the player feel good to win the first round of the first match and encourages them to play more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: BTW the CPU difficulty is not reduced in round 2 if you have previously won round 1.
